text: To the Editor:

headline: CBS-Viacom Reunion? Redstones May Seek a Better Deal
text: The Redstones do like to keep everyone on their toes. The family that controls the media firms CBS and Viacom on Monday vetoed their proposal for the companies to merge. The Murdochs’ bid for Sky and AT&T’s deal for Time Warner have ignited the industry’s animal spirits. That has raised the prospect that reuniting with Viacom would rob CBS of a better offer.

headline: Golden Globe Nominee Reactions
text: Mahershala Ali is not at all used to awards fuss — which explains his leisurely, earnest manner while chatting with the Bagger this morning after the announcement of his widely expected Golden Globe nomination for best supporting actor for his performance in “Moonlight.”

headline: Corporate Welfare Won’t Create Jobs
text: Washington — The recent deal to keep some 800 workers employed at a Carrier plant in Indiana rather than see those jobs shipped to Mexico proved great news for the workers and a public relations bonanza for President-elect Donald J. Trump.

headline: New Approach to Corporate Tax Law Has House G.O.P. Support
text: President-elect Donald J. Trump has vowed to protect and create American manufacturing jobs, even threatening high tariffs on imports to help achieve that goal. So far, though, his plan seems to lean heavily on one-at-a-time deals, like the one struck late last month to save jobs at the Carrier plant in Indianapolis.

headline: Trump Joins Line of Critics of Costly Fighter Jet
text: WASHINGTON — President-elect Donald J. Trump said on Monday that the cost of building the military’s next-generation fighter jet, the F-35 Joint Strike Fighter, had spiraled “out of control,” and he vowed to save billions of dollars on military programs once he enters office next month.

headline: New York City’s Child Welfare Commissioner, Gladys Carrión, Resigns
text: New York City Mayor Bill de Blasio announced on Monday that his child welfare commissioner was stepping down after a succession of deaths that renewed long-running concerns about the city’s supervision of vulnerable children.

headline: Russia and the U.S. Election: What We Know and Don’t Know
text: The swirl of revelations and allegations about Russian involvement in the American presidential election, which has been building since the summer, can be difficult to keep straight.

headline: Prudential Suspends Sales of Its Life Policies by Wells Fargo
text: In a sign of widening fallout from Wells Fargo’s sales scandal, Prudential said Monday that it was suspending sales of its life insurance policies through Wells Fargo until it completed an investigation into the bank’s sales tactics.

headline: Veronica Webb, Overseer of Pizza Parties
text: “It’s not glamorous taking out the recycling,” Veronica Webb said, as she carried a basket of plastic bottles and cardboard down the hall of her Upper West Side apartment.

headline: M.T.A. Races to Finish 2nd Avenue Subway as Deadline Looms
text: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority is rushing to finish the long-delayed Second Avenue subway this month, but officials at a board meeting Monday once again did not announce an opening date, with less than three weeks left to meet their deadline, Dec. 31.

headline: Afrofuturism: The Next Generation
text: In the September issue of W magazine, Rihanna was cast as Tomorrow, an otherworldly warrior queen and champion of the downtrodden, resplendent in diamonds and foil.

headline: San Francisco Symphony Cancels North Carolina Concerts, Citing Anti-Gay-Rights Law
text: The San Francisco Symphony announced on Monday that it had canceled a pair of April concerts in North Carolina to protest the new state law curbing anti-discrimination protections for lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgender people.

headline: Donald Trump vs. the C.I.A. on Russia
text: To the Editor:

headline: Los Angeles Rams Fire Coach Jeff Fisher Shortly After Giving Him an Extension
text: A little more than a week after acknowledging that Coach Jeff Fisher’s contract was extended through 2018, the Los Angeles Rams changed course and fired him on Monday. The decision came one day after a 42-14 loss to the Atlanta Falcons, which ensured that the Rams would have a losing record for the 10th consecutive season, and three days before a prime-time matchup against the Seattle Seahawks on Thursday.

headline: Trump Style vs. Texas Style: Who’s Angry Now?
text: Times Insider delivers behind-the-scenes insights from The New York Times. In this postcard, our Houston bureau chief debunks the notion that Donald Trump’s victory is a sign of the Tex-ification of America.

headline: Goldman President Named Trump Adviser, Opening Door for Younger Executives
text: The jockeying to be the next chief executive of Goldman Sachs is expected to intensify after President-elect Donald J. Trump officially asked the firm’s president, Gary D. Cohn, to become his top economic policy adviser on Monday.

headline: Rodrigo Duterte Criticizes Times Coverage of Philippine Drug Campaign
text: MANILA — The office of President Rodrigo Duterte of the Philippines protested on Monday that a New York Times article and photographic essay on the country’s antidrug campaign had been “totally one-sided.”

headline: Kenley Jansen Said to Agree to Five-Year, $80 Million Deal With Dodgers
text: For years, no closer had been paid more than $15 million a season. That was the benchmark set by the Yankees’ Mariano Rivera, who also has the career saves record. For the first three off-seasons after Rivera’s retirement, in 2013, nobody challenged his salary standard.

headline: In Aleppo, Displaced Returning to Rubble
text: Syrian government forces have retaken large parts of rebel-held neighborhoods in eastern Aleppo, leaving few areas under opposition control on Monday.

headline: Declassify the Senate Torture Report
text: This editorial has been updated to reflect news developments.

headline: RICO Charge in Pharmaceutical Case May Signal Tougher Tactics
text: One of the most powerful tools in the Justice Department’s arsenal is the Racketeer Influenced and Corrupt Organizations Act, better known as RICO, that can result in long prison sentences for members of criminal organizations. Although the law has rarely been used against corporate executives, an indictment that includes a RICO conspiracy charge last week in a health care fraud case in Boston could signal a more aggressive approach to violations involving senior management.

headline: How Trump’s Education Nominee Bent Detroit to Her Will on Charter Schools
text: Few disagreed that schools in Detroit were a mess: a chaotic mix of charters and traditional public schools, the worst-performing in the nation.

headline: 8 Holiday Shows for Various Tastes
text: Need a break from the hunt for Hatchimals or from eyeball-detonating Christmas displays? Here’s our guide to eight affordable shows for eight holiday theater tastes, from I-can’t-get-enough-tinsel traditionalists to Santa-is-for-suckers holiday haters.

headline: Donald Trump, Aleppo, Golden Globes: Your Monday Evening Briefing
text: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Interpreting Kanye West’s Blond ’Do
text: Kanye West, the rapper, fashion designer, showman and Twitter ranter, has maintained a low profile since canceling his “Saint Pablo” tour and being hospitalized in mid-November amid rumors of severe exhaustion.

headline: 'The Dream Life of Astronauts,’ Hopes Too Fragile for the Cold
text: The stories by Patrick Ryan in “The Dream Life of Astronauts” take place in and around Cape Canaveral, Fla. Some of his characters work for NASA — or did, before they fell back into the slipstream of ordinary life. Some simply live nearby on Merritt Island, where they can watch shuttle launches from their backyards. One man, who helped double- and triple-check the thermal tiles on the doomed orbiter Challenger, feels rattled for a long time after the 1986 disaster.

headline: ‘Taste NY’ Markets Pit the State Against Federal Regulators
text: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo’s “Taste NY” program seemed simple enough: Slap some new branding on the blue billboards that line New York State’s roadways, establish markets that sell local products at places frequented by travelers and hold events across the state featuring homegrown goods.

headline: Pep Guardiola: A Continental Success and English Soccer’s Measuring Stick
text: The criticism itself will neither surprise nor sting Pep Guardiola. He made that perfectly clear months ago, on the day he was presented as Manchester City manager.

headline: Celebrity Polaroids Give New Life to Dead Film
text: There was a time when the term “instant” brought to mind not an iPhone snap but the simple bliss of seeing a film pop through a Polaroid camera, fixing a giddy moment onto a memory that would last a lifetime (provided the photograph didn’t fade).

headline: New York Education Department Drops Plan to Merge 2 Harlem Schools
text: New York City’s Education Department is withdrawing a plan to merge two elementary schools in southern Harlem after receiving criticism that it had not given parents enough time to respond, it said on Monday.

headline: Veterans Groups Urge Trump to Keep Obama’s V.A. Secretary
text: The nation’s largest veterans groups are urging President-elect Donald J. Trump to keep President Obama’s secretary of veterans affairs, Robert A. McDonald, out of concern that his rumored candidates’ inexperience and ideological leanings could cripple the massive veterans health care system.

headline: Blackhawks’ Marian Hossa, an Elder Statesman, Adapts to Run With a Younger Crowd
text: CHICAGO — Marian Hossa arrived in Trencin, his hometown in Slovakia, in May, returning to family and friends months earlier than he had in recent memory.

headline: Cathedral Bombing in Cairo Leaves Egypt Alarmed, and Its President Scrambling
text: CAIRO — President Abdel Fattah el-Sisi on Monday made dramatic efforts to reassure Egypt’s Coptic Christians — a pillar of his government’s support — as they buried victims of a bombing on Sunday at their cathedral in Cairo, an act that has stirred fears of resurgent Islamist violence.

headline: Detroit and the Pistons Are One Again
text: Motown is not going back to Detroit but the Pistons are. This recent news, capping a standup year of N.B.A. social activism and outspokenness, was soul-cleansing music to Dave Bing’s ears.

headline: Venezuela’s Government Plays Santa, After Seizing Millions of Toys
text: CARACAS, Venezuela — It was a haul that might have even given Santa Claus pause: 3.8 million toys, seized by Venezuela’s government on the grounds that their owners were hoarding castles and kiddie cars ahead of Christmas.

headline: Donald Trump’s Wealthy Cabinet Picks to Undergo Financial Scrutiny He Didn’t Face
text: WASHINGTON — For the billionaires, the multimillionaires and the plain well-off people whom President-elect Donald J. Trump is choosing for his cabinet, the first step to office will be the sort of grilling he didn’t face — on potential business conflicts of interest and, for some, tax returns — courtesy of the Senate sleuths who have taken their toll in the past.

headline: N.F.L. Concussion Settlement Payments Can Begin After Supreme Court Defers
text: The United States Supreme Court on Monday denied a request to review the N.F.L.’s settlement with retired players who had accused the league of hiding the dangers of head trauma, paving the way for some players with brain ailments to begin receiving payments of as much as $5 million.

headline: In Patz Trial, Suspect’s Family Tells of His Odd Behavior
text: He demanded that his daughter hold his hand as she crossed the street, even though she was a teenager. He could be stubborn and taciturn and strict with his rules. He warned his daughter about a dark world — one in which there “were no good people.”

headline: Yankees Sign Former Mets Infielder Ruben Tejada to Minor League Deal
text: Ruben Tejada, the infielder whose tenure with the Mets ended when he broke his leg during the 2015 playoffs, signed a minor league contract with the Yankees on Monday, according to his agent, Peter Greenberg. The deal includes an invitation to major league camp.

headline: Donald Trump Says His Company Will Do ‘No New Deals’ During His Term
text: WASHINGTON — President-elect Donald J. Trump said late Monday night that “no new deals will be done” by his real estate business while he is in the Oval Office, a promise that appeared meant to address ethical concerns about conflicts of interest between his elected position and his real estate empire.

headline: Bill Gates Leads New Fund as Fears of U.S. Retreat on Climate Grow
text: President-elect Donald J. Trump has bred fears that the United States will take a back seat in global efforts to tackle climate change.

headline: Elizabeth Warren Condemns the Wrong Man
text: Senator Elizabeth Warren, furious about President-elect Donald J. Trump’s appointments of finance industry insiders, took to Facebook a little over a week ago to fire off a message to her nearly 2.5 million followers.

headline: Labor Secretary Thomas Perez Is Said to Plan Run to Lead D.N.C.
text: WASHINGTON — Labor Secretary Thomas E. Perez has told three senior Democrats that he intends to run for chairman of the Democratic National Committee, challenging the front-running candidate, Representative Keith Ellison, and inserting an ally of President Obama into the contest to rebuild a bruised party.

headline: A. A. Gill, Who Gleefully Skewered Britain’s Restaurants, Dies at 62
text: A. A. Gill, an essayist and cultural critic whose stylishly malicious restaurant reviews for The Sunday Times made him one of Britain’s most celebrated journalists, died on Saturday in London. He was 62.

headline: Flawed Choices for the State Department
text: Set aside the fact that Rex Tillerson, the chief executive of Exxon Mobil and Donald Trump’s choice for secretary of state, knows scores of world leaders and is a skilled businessman. Why would Mr. Trump choose as his top diplomat a man whose every decision or action would be tainted by suspicion that he’s capitulating to Russian interests or those of the oil industry, having spent his entire career at Exxon Mobil?

headline: Quotation of the Day
text: “My aim is to turn my mustache yellow — I’ll smoke as long as my health allows it.”

headline: Michael Flynn Is Harsh Judge of C.I.A.’s Role
text: WASHINGTON — Long before Lt. Gen. Michael T. Flynn became Donald J. Trump’s choice for national security adviser, he believed that the Central Intelligence Agency had become a political tool of the Obama administration — a view now echoed by the president-elect in his mocking dismissals of C.I.A. assessments that Russia sought to tip the election in Mr. Trump’s favor.

headline: Esma Redzepova Dies at 73; Sang of Her Roma Heritage to Generations
text: Esma Redzepova, the Macedonian singer who was acclaimed for decades as the greatest female voice in Romany (Gypsy) music, died on Sunday in Skopje, the capital of Macedonia. She was 73.

headline: Times Insider Photo Challenge: Caption This!
text: Times Insider shares insights into how we work at The New York Times. Occasionally we have some fun.

headline: Hack of Quest Diagnostics App Exposes Data of 34,000 Patients
text: A medical laboratory company based in New Jersey said Monday that it was investigating a recent hack that exposed the personal health information of about 34,000 people.

headline: Rex Tillerson’s Company, Exxon, Has Billions at Stake Over Sanctions on Russia
text: MOSCOW — Now that President-elect Donald J. Trump has chosen Rex W. Tillerson, the chief executive of Exxon Mobil, to be the next secretary of state, the giant oil company stands to make some major gains as well: It has billions of dollars in deals that can go forward only if the United States lifts sanctions against Russia.

headline: Review: Jealousy and Lies in a No-Exit Theater of War in ‘Othello’
text: “I am your own forever.” When these words are uttered in the electrifying new production of “Othello,” which opened on Monday night at the New York Theater Workshop, you feel you’ve heard the most frightening vow ever spoken. It is delivered at the end of the first half of a performance that is drawn in lightning.

headline: Legal Precedents
text: I do love a punny debut, and today we solve The New York Times debut puzzle of David Alfred Bywaters, who has a name that is more reminiscent of a Victorian novelist than a crossword constructor in 2016.

headline: Rex Tillerson, Exxon C.E.O., Chosen as Secretary of State
text: WASHINGTON — President-elect Donald J. Trump on Tuesday officially selected Rex W. Tillerson, the chief executive of Exxon Mobil, to be his secretary of state. In saying he will nominate Mr. Tillerson, the president-elect is dismissing bipartisan concerns that the globe-trotting leader of an energy giant has a too-cozy relationship with Vladimir V. Putin, the president of Russia.

headline: António Guterres, Sworn In as U.N.’s Next Leader, Must Factor Trump Into His Plans
text: UNITED NATIONS — António Guterres took the oath of office  on Monday to become the next secretary general of the United Nations amid a rise in nationalist movements around the world and what he called a loss of confidence in institutions, including the one he will take over in January.

headline: Watch Where You’re Going
text: Dear Diary,

headline: Meet Exxon’s Rex Tillerson, Trump’s Choice for Secretary of State
text: Rex W. Tillerson, the chief executive of Exxon Mobil, was offered the job of secretary of state by President-elect Donald J. Trump on Tuesday.

headline: Plane Bound for Germany Is Diverted to Kennedy Airport After Bomb Threat
text: A plane bound for Germany was diverted to Kennedy International Airport on Monday as the authorities investigated a bomb threat called in about the flight.

headline: India Hobbles Through a Cash Crisis, and Electronic Payments Boom
text: NEW DELHI — For a year, Ashish Kumar Mandal scratched out a living selling dumplings on the streets of New Delhi for a bit less than 50 cents a plate, until the government banned most of the country’s currency bills last month, crushing his all-cash business. In desperation, the 32-year-old took a step he had never even contemplated before: He offered his customers the option of paying electronically.

headline: Record Number of Journalists Jailed in 2016, Press Advocacy Group Says
text: At least 259 journalists have been jailed around the world this year, a press advocacy group reported on Monday, the most since it began a detailed annual census of imprisonments in 1990.

headline: Aleppo, Donald Trump, Paolo Gentiloni: Your Tuesday Briefing
text: Good morning.

headline: Mike Pence Is Invited to Dine at Pizzeria at Center of Fake News Barrage
text: Vice President-elect Mike Pence received a surprise dinner invitation on Monday night from his new neighbors in leafy northwest Washington. They asked him to dine with them at Comet Ping Pong, the pizzeria at the center of debate over whether allies of President-elect Donald J. Trump are spreading so-called fake news.

headline: From Botswana to Zambia, New Lodges, Resorts and Tours
text: To stay or to roam? That is the African question. The following new and improved accommodations, from Indian Ocean island resorts and highland volcano lodges to hotels in working vineyards and solar-powered desert camps, capture the continent’s diversity. Meanwhile, the latest tours take roads less traveled, from the desert of Sudan to migratory grounds in Zambia.

headline: What’s on TV Tuesday: ‘Rock the Troops’ and ‘The Voice’ Season Finale
text: The Rock and an army of other performers entertain the troops. Dolly Parton sings out in support of victims of the Smoky Mountain wildfires. And Bruno Mars, Sting and the Weeknd take the stage on the season finale of “The Voice.”

headline: Corrections: December 13, 2016
text: NEW YORK

headline: Child Sexual Abuse Scandal Rocks U.K. Soccer
text: MARTON, England — Andrew Woodward grew up with a soccer ball between his feet. His room, in a working-class housing estate, was filled with posters of famous players and his head with dreams of becoming a defender for England. When he was 9, he scored a goal from the halfway line in a school match and raced across the field into the arms of his father, who said he was “the proudest dad in the world.”

headline: Word + Quiz: supernumerary
text: adjective: more than is needed, desired, or required

headline: Reclaimed Memories
text: Through the Lost Rolls America project, anyone can send in an undeveloped roll of 35mm, 120mm, or E6 film and have it scanned and printed for free. Here are some of the images collected so far.

headline: Forget AT&T. The Real Monopolies Are Google and Facebook.
text: The proposed merger of AT&T and Time Warner has drawn censure from both sides of the political aisle, as well as a Senate hearing that looked into the potential for the combined company to become a monopoly.

headline: The Personality Politics of ‘The Crown’
text: At first, “The Crown” seems like perfect postelection escapism.

headline: What Is America Without Influence? Trump Will Find Out.
text: WASHINGTON — In February 1945, in the twilight of World War II, Franklin D. Roosevelt, Joseph Stalin and Winston Churchill convened in Yalta, a Russian resort town in the Crimea, to deliberate on the direction of the war and the peace to follow. They agreed to a postwar order managed by Roosevelt’s “Four Policemen” — the United States, Britain, Russia and China.

headline: From Many Corners, Journalism Seeking Solutions
text: The goal of journalism, in the words of Carl Bernstein, is to provide the “best obtainable version of the truth.” This is hard to do. It’s not just a matter of sorting fact from fiction, dealing with “filter bubbles” and motivated denial of facts, or even contending with the public’s lack of trust for journalists.

headline: Betsy DeVos and God’s Plan for Schools
text: BOSTON — At the rightmost edge of the Christian conservative movement, there are those who dream of turning the United States into a Christian republic subject to “biblical laws.” In the unlikely figure of Donald J. Trump, they hope to have found their greatest champion yet. He wasn’t “our preferred candidate,” the Christian nationalist David Barton said in June, but he could be “God’s candidate.”

headline: Make Colleges Diverse
text: Many college campuses have reacted to Donald Trump’s election with shock and angst. Professors and students are wondering how the rest of the country could be so different from them. The more introspective are asking: What can we do?

headline: Alabama Prosecutor Sets the Penalties and Fills the Coffers
text: DOTHAN, Ala. — It was a run-of-the-mill keg party in an open field, until one guest, Harvey Drayton Burch III, objected to paying for his beer. Witnesses said Mr. Burch fired a gun over the crowd and began spraying Mace. With partyers fleeing, Mr. Burch jumped into the back seat of a car as it drove away.

headline: A Remarkable Find
text: Imagine you are exploring somewhere in the world, and you come across something of important historic, scientific or artistic merit. What would you like it to be?

headline: UniCredit to Cut 14,000 Jobs and Raise Nearly $14 Billion in Overhaul
text: LONDON — UniCredit, Italy’s largest bank by assets, said on Tuesday that it planned to cut 14,000 jobs over the next three years and that it would seek to raise nearly $14 billion, part of a strategic overhaul that comes at a crucial time for the country’s troubled banking sector.

headline: A Mission to Rescue Forgotten Photos
text: If you ever visit a photographer’s home and peek in the refrigerator, you’re likely to find a bag of undeveloped film stuck way in the back, near an ancient box of baking soda. (Yes, that includes this photographer’s refrigerator.) It’s a near universal phenomenon — little spools of celluloid, chilled and never explored.

headline: Questions for: ‘Russian Hackers Acted to Aid Trump in Election, U.S. Says’
text: Article: Russian Hackers Acted to Aid Trump in Election, U.S. Says

headline: What Comes After Aleppo Falls?
text: The battle for eastern Aleppo will be over soon, but tens of thousands of Syrians  there will find little peace. The victory for the government of President Bashar al-Assad will open another violent, disorienting chapter in their lives, and a dangerous one for the opposition. Soon, civilians and rebel fighters alike will either be punished or have to flee the city and join the many thousands of others displaced by Mr. Assad and his Iranian and Russian allies — part of a plan to break the insurgency, and change Syria forever.

headline: Asahi to Buy Beer Brands From Anheuser-Busch InBev for $7.8 Billion
text: Asahi Group, the Japanese beer giant, said on Tuesday that it would pay $7.8 billion to buy a group of Central and Eastern European beer brands from Anheuser-Busch InBev, in the latest brand shuffle for the rapidly consolidating brewing business.

headline: The Twists and Turns of ‘La Marseillaise’
text: PARIS — Last November, immediately after the Bataclan terror attacks here, France’s national anthem took on a global significance that few would have predicted. “La Marseillaise” was sung at rallies across the country, in English soccer stadiums and American concert halls.

headline: Who’s Responsible When Extremists Get a Platform?
text: In the days immediately following the presidential election, one striking statement by Stephen K. Bannon, the president-elect’s chief strategist and former campaign chief executive, rose to particular prominence. Speaking in July in his capacity as the chairman of Breitbart News, Bannon told the journalist Sarah Posner, in an article for Mother Jones, that his site was “the platform for the alt-right.” The statement was interpreted as both a claim of credit and a sort of explanation. The man who helped guide Donald J. Trump to the White House, and who will guide him again as president, had revealed the connection between his candidate, his publication and America’s most noxious political faction — a recently emboldened white-nationalist movement. And not only that, he seemed proud of it.

headline: What the West Can Learn From Japan About the Cultural Value of Work
text: A few weeks ago, in a Kyoto tempura bar, I watched a lone chef, a man in late middle age, cooking behind a counter for his 11 customers. The set menu had 15 items on it. That meant that at any given moment, he was keeping track of 165 pieces of food, each subject to slightly different timing and technique. He wrote nothing down and expended no apparent effort. It was a demonstration of total mastery. This didn’t look so much like a job as a life: His work was his whole being.

headline: When Trump Meets Tech Leaders, Jobs Will Be on the Agenda
text: SAN FRANCISCO — At the top of the agenda when President-elect Donald J. Trump meets with tech leaders on Wednesday afternoon: jobs, jobs and more jobs.

headline: Al Franken Faces Donald Trump and the Next Four Years
text: ‘Donald Trump never laughs,” Al Franken said.

headline: In Sacred Grove in Nigeria, Worship and Connection
text: The ritual drummers preceded her as she strode down the broad steps toward the Osun shrine, carefully balancing on her head a calabash filled with kola nuts, palm oil and other offerings to the Yoruba gods. She was not used to walking barefoot, so the sticks and stones on the forest floor sometimes hurt her feet, yet she continued on her course with a trancelike resolve. It was all part of an initiation ceremony of the traditional Ifa religion of the Yoruba, the largest ethnic group in southwest Nigeria, and the main reason she had traveled to the Osun-Osogbo Sacred Grove in Nigeria. At home in Brooklyn people know her as AnnMarie Sealey. Here in Osogbo they call her Ifaseye Orisabunmi Adeegbe.

headline: Mexico Grapples With a Surge in Violence
text: CIUDAD JUÁREZ, Mexico — Five men shot dead in a barbershop, their bodies slumped near the doorway. A decapitated body dumped next to a housing development. Three others killed behind a pool hall and several more in a bar called Tres Mentiras, or Three Lies.

headline: After Oakland Fire, Brooklyn Artists Vow to Keep Partying
text: Just before midnight on Wednesday, two young women with shaved heads slipped into a hallway during a party at a commercial building in Brooklyn and removed their clothes. While a man wearing a neoprene jumpsuit and knee-high boots crooned in a nearby room, the women crawled under a plastic tarp and began to grapple, a 10-minute piece of performance art that ended with them covered in handprints of black ink as an appreciative audience applauded.

headline: Where Were Trump’s Votes? Where the Jobs Weren’t
text: Did the white working class vote its economic interests?

headline: Should Cheerleading Be an Olympic Sport?
text: Watch the video above. Does it accurately depict your image of what cheerleaders are and do?

headline: The Most Talked-About Debates of 2016
text: Here are the 10 discussions that got the most readers to weigh in with their comments.

headline: Morning Agenda: Trump and Wall Street, Wells Fargo Fallout, Beer Sales
text: The competition is heating up at Goldman Sachs.

headline: Rex Tillerson, Aleppo, Golden Globe Awards: Your Tuesday Briefing
text: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Seeing Africa by Road
text: We had made it to Tete, Mozambique. The sun was sinking behind the Zambezi River like a scoop of orange sherbet as we sat on the motel’s deck taking in the quiet close of another long day on the road. But we avoided one another’s eyes. The table in front of us was cluttered with maps, notebooks, competing spreadsheets and empty beer bottles.

headline: Aya Cash: The First Time I Ate a Vegetable (I Was 22)
text: I grew up in San Francisco, land of organic vegetables and vegan delights, before such things were so popular. From an early age, my parents sent me to school with peanut-butter-and-honey sandwiches, hard-boiled eggs, and fresh fruit from the fields of the Central Valley. Although I had every opportunity to eat delicious and nutritious food, I never met a vegetable I liked.

headline: New York Today: The Animals of 2016
text: Updated, 7:04 a.m.

headline: 2,300 U.S. Foreclosures Show a Racial Divide in House Decay
text: The message from broken mailboxes: Fair-housing advocates say Fannie Mae lets homes deteriorate more in certain neighborhoods.

headline: Battle Over Aleppo Is Over, Russia Says, as Evacuation Deal Reached
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Russia declared on Tuesday that the four-year battle over Aleppo, Syria’s largest city, was over, as the last remaining rebel fighters agreed to turn over their territory to the Syrian government. While pro-government forces were moving in, United Nations officials said they were receiving multiple reports of execution-style killings.

headline: Obama Names ‘Red Lines’ That Would Pull Him Back Into Political Fray
text: ■ The “red lines” that would bring President Obama back into the political fray.

headline: California Today: A Push to Legalize Sidewalk Vending in Los Angeles
text: Good morning.

headline: Trump Lines Up Establishment Republicans to Vouch for Rex Tillerson
text: WASHINGTON — After waging an 18-month assault on the Republican establishment, President-elect Donald J. Trump changed course on Tuesday and enlisted the party’s high priests of foreign policy to help him win the confirmation of Rex W. Tillerson as secretary of state.

headline: An (Edible) Solution to Extend Produce’s Shelf Life
text: SANTA BARBARA, Calif. — What if a Florida tomato could be left on the vine long enough to turn red and fully develop its flavor — and still be ripe and juicy when it arrived at a grocery store in New York days later?

headline: When Politics Became a Fashion Statement
text: It was the year politics took over our closets, and clothes went beyond products to become positions.

headline: Governor of Jakarta Issues Tearful Denial as Blasphemy Trial Opens in Indonesia
text: JAKARTA, Indonesia — The Christian governor of Jakarta, the capital of Indonesia, the world’s most populous Muslim-majority nation, tearfully denied on Tuesday that he had intended to insult Islam as his trial on blasphemy charges began.

headline: London Gets More N.F.L. Games. Too Bad About the Teams.
text: Hey, London! You love American football? Well, great news, we’re sending you the Browns!

headline: Rick Perry, Ex-Governor of Texas, Is Trump’s Pick as Energy Secretary
text: WASHINGTON — President-elect Donald J. Trump plans to name Rick Perry, the former governor of Texas, to lead the Energy Department, an agency far more devoted to national security and basic science than to the extraction of fossil fuels that is Mr. Perry’s expertise.

headline: Virtual Reality Stories That Transported Viewers in 2016
text: This year The Times published over fifteen groundbreaking virtual reality films that allow you to experience  a range of stories, from standing on the surface of Pluto to the battle to retake Falluja from ISIS this past summer. Below are some of our favorites. Download the NYT VR app on iPhone or Android to watch these films on your smartphone.

headline: Christians in U.S. Are Less Educated Than Religious Minorities, Report Says
text: Religious minorities in the United States are far more likely to have attended college or a vocational school than members of the Christian majority, according to a review of census and survey data from 151 countries released on Tuesday that found wide gaps in education among followers of the world’s major religions.

headline: Pitching In to Preserve Aviation History
text: DAYTON, Ohio — On a chilly fall afternoon, 4-year-old Antoine Alston and his 8-year-old sister, De’Asia Liggins, waited for the bus with their mother on the western side of this city. Behind them was an abandoned factory of historical significance, but that was news to the children.

headline: Sites for Aviation Buffs
text: The Dayton area has more than a dozen sites for aviation enthusiasts to visit, including the bicycle shop occupied in 1892 by the Wright Brothers and the Baptist church where Orville Wright’s funeral was held in 1948. Among the options are five stops specific to the birth of flight that are part of the official Dayton Aviation Heritage National Historical Park.

headline: In Arizona County Where Latinos Have an Edge, So Did Trump
text: YUMA, Ariz. — For all the talk on the campaign trail of a border wall and mass deportations, it was Donald J. Trump’s pledge to create more jobs, lift wages and increase opportunities that persuaded Latinos in this majority-minority city 30 miles north of Mexico to vote for him.

headline: Can Smuggled TV Shows Change North Korea?
text: Last summer, I had breakfast with a teenager who had just completed a crash course that seeks to help North Korean defectors adapt to their new lives in the South. As a poor orphan in North Korea, he survived harsh winters by smuggling foreign films across the frozen Tumen River. He would stuff cash into women’s stockings and hurl them across narrow parts of the river. On the other side, his Chinese counterparts would fill up the stockings with DVDs and thumb drives and slide them back.

headline: To Be or Not to Be a Dictator
text: On Dec. 2, Yahya Jammeh, the dictator of the small West African country Gambia, did something remarkably undictatorial: He agreed to step down after losing an election. But a week later, he reverted to type, appearing live on state television to reject the results.

headline: Afghanistan Vice President Accused of Torturing Political Rival
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — A political rival of Vice President Abdul Rashid Dostum of Afghanistan said on Tuesday that he had been tortured and raped with an assault rifle after being abducted by General Dostum last month.

headline: The Most-Read Times Obituaries of 2016
text: The most-read obituaries of 2016, in order of readership.

headline: Kanye West Visits Donald Trump
text: After weeks of reports of severe exhaustion and ensuing hospitalization, Kanye West walked into Trump Tower on Tuesday morning.

headline: Colombia Needs Help to Make Peace Last
text: OSLO — On Nov. 29, a 6-year-old Colombian girl, Yisely Isarama, was killed by a land mine in Choco Province. The same day, the Colombian Senate voted 75 to 0 to ratify peace accords to end the 52-year war between the government and the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia, known as the FARC.

headline: AGMES’s Simple, Sleek Jewelry
text: The brand founded by Morgan and Jaclyn Solomon is subtly understated.

headline: You Are Not Getting Hungry …: Using Hypnosis to Avoid Holiday Weight Gain
text: You are getting sleepy … you are getting in touch with your subconscious … you are going to skip the dessert table at your company’s holiday party … in fact, you do not even like desserts.

headline: Brand to Know: an Understated Jewelry Line Made by Sisters
text: “I always subconsciously wanted to have a jewelry line, but I guess I never really thought I could do it,” says the designer Morgan Solomon, 27. After graduating from college, she instead decided to pursue a career in the buying department at Bloomingdale’s. “I always thought of my sister as being the really creative one in the family. I didn’t see it as my path.” (Her sister, Jaclyn, 33, was a knitwear designer at Proenza Schouler at the time.)

headline: A Trump Economic Boom? The Fed May Stand in the Way
text: WASHINGTON — Investors in financial markets, and those predicting faster economic growth in 2017, would do well to remember the famous words that William McChesney Martin Jr., the former Federal Reserve chairman, uttered way back in 1955: The Fed’s job is to remove the punch bowl just as the party gets going.

headline: 1916: Greek Legation Tenders France Official Regret
text: The Greek Legation in Paris last night issued the following Note:— “The Greek Chargé d’Affaires has called on the Minister for Foreign Affairs to express to the Government of the French Republic, in the name of the King and the Athens Government, their sincere regret at the events which took place in Athens, which they deplore.”

headline: The Russian Doping Scandal Keeps on Growing
text: With Russia standing accused of meddling in American politics and in Syria and Ukraine, new revelations about Russian doping in sports might seem anti-climactic. Yet the mountain of new evidence laid out by Richard McLaren, the Canadian lawyer appointed by the World Anti-Doping Agency (WADA) to investigate Russia’s doping program, is astounding.

headline: Back on Her Feet at 85, Thanks to a Chair
text: In the middle of Marilyn Oshman’s otherwise cozy apartment on the Lower East Side of Manhattan, between an antique candelabra, flower-covered curtains and framed family photos, was a hospital bed.

headline: Tunisian Captain in Deadly Migrant Shipwreck Jailed for 18 Years
text: ROME — A Tunisian captain who was piloting a fishing vessel crammed with migrants that collided with another ship, resulting in the deaths of about 700 people traveling to Italy from Libya, was sentenced on Tuesday to 18 years in prison.

headline: Aleksei Navalny, Putin Critic, Says He’ll Run for President of Russia
text: MOSCOW — Aleksei A. Navalny, the most vocal critic of the Kremlin, announced on Tuesday his intention to run for president of Russia, though he is facing a court trial that could make him ineligible to participate in the campaign.

headline: After Many Missed Deadlines, New Jersey Megamall Is Again Taking Shape
text: Over the last 13 years, opening dates for a huge shopping and entertainment complex in the Meadowlands have flashed by like exits on the New Jersey Turnpike, which runs past the site of the long-delayed project in East Rutherford, N.J.

headline: He’s the Michael Jordan of Darts. He Just Has to Prove It.
text: OLDHAM, England — In an exposition hall eight miles outside Manchester, on a softly humming treadmill stripped of its handrails, the best darts player in the world was trying to keep his balance and his cool.

headline: Shall They Dance? Making ‘La La Land’ Move
text: The choreographer Mandy Moore was under pressure. But it wasn’t because she was shooting a scene involving 30 dancers, 100 extras and at least 60 cars on an exit ramp connecting two major freeways in Los Angeles.

headline: News in the Era of Trump
text: When you feel like you need your reality checked.

headline: Daily Report: Tech Executives Meeting Trump Are in a Tough Spot
text: Talk about a no-win situation that many leaders of the biggest tech companies have found themselves in.

headline: Jake Gyllenhaal to Star in Broadway Revival of ‘Sunday in the Park’
text: Jake Gyllenhaal will return to Broadway next year in a brief revival of “Sunday in the Park With George.”

headline: With ‘Trousergate,’ Politics and Pants Collide in Britain
text: LONDON — Never mind Britain’s tortuous decision to leave the European Union. Lately, another matter of state has been preoccupying Britons across the realm: a $1,250 pair of “desert khaki” leather pants.

headline: The Twitter Post, Take 2
text: Q. Do apps like TweetDeck let you edit Twitter posts?

headline: Recent Commercial Real Estate Transactions
text: 555-557 Union Street (between Nevins Street and Third Avenue)

headline: U.N. Drops Wonder Woman as an Ambassador
text: The United Nations has ended a campaign featuring Wonder Woman as an ambassador for women and girls, two months after the announcement was met with protests and a petition complaining that the fictional superhero was an inappropriate choice to represent female empowerment.

headline: Year of Upheaval for Restaurants That Ended Tipping
text: The owners of Huertas, a cheerful Spanish small-plates restaurant in the East Village, knew they would have to raise prices when they abolished tipping last December. But when the octopus plate rose to $21 from $16, they looked at the plate and realized another adjustment was needed.

headline: Review: ‘Rogue One’ Leaves ‘Star Wars’ Fans Wanting More and Less
text: The great mystery of “Rogue One” — the big payoff, the thing people like me would be pilloried for divulging, the puzzle you will congratulate yourself for solving — is where it fits in with the rest of the “Star Wars” cycle. There are scattered hints early on, and later appearances by familiar characters that elicit chuckles of recognition from fans. The very last shot tells us exactly where we are, and why we should have cared about everything we just saw.

headline: Exxon’s Next Chief Will Lead a Weakened Empire
text: Exxon Mobil’s next chief executive will confront a weakened empire in 2017. With its current boss, Rex Tillerson, selected as Donald Trump’s secretary of state, the likely successor, Darren Woods, will take charge of the $380 billion oil giant in the face of still-weak prices and falling reserves.

headline: Tending to the Living and the Dead in a Battle-Torn Afghan City
text: KUNDUZ, Afghanistan — Allah Mohammed, 37, helps sustain life, baking bread all day in the small oven of his corner shop in Kunduz city. Part of his bakery’s ceiling remains caved in where it was hit by a rocket during the latest Taliban siege.

headline: Café Carlyle Season Includes Debuts from Isaac Mizrahi and Jill Kargman
text: Café Carlyle’s winter season will be headlined by two performers from outside the music world: Isaac Mizrahi and Jill Kargman.

headline: A Top Defender, Sidelined by the Accused in the Charleston Church Massacre
text: CHARLESTON, S.C. — David I. Bruck has spent decades crafting legal strategies to keep people out of the country’s execution chambers. He has argued before the United States Supreme Court on seven occasions, winning six times. He has frustrated prosecutors, challenged judges and softened grim-faced juries.

headline: Google Parent Company Spins Off Self-Driving Car Business
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Google’s self-driving car is ready to take the wheel.

headline: Top New York Restaurants of 2016
text: Visit the kitchens and dining rooms of New York's best restaurants of the year.

headline: The Top 10 Restaurants of 2016
text: Pete Wells names his favorite restaurants in New York City this year.

headline: Top New York Restaurants of 2016
text: No one person can review every new restaurant in New York, but not long ago, I felt confident that I could hit all the ones where a customer who had a full dinner and no drinks would spend, say, $125 or more. I didn’t always choose to weigh in, but those cases were rare.

headline: Citi Bike Stations
text: To the Editor:

headline: Where to Watch the Best TV of 2016
text: We are so close to saying goodbye to 2016. Until then, it’s time to feast on end-of-year lists. There are enough out there to sustain you through the next couple of weeks, and one course on your menu should be the New York Times critics’ picks for the best TV of the year.

headline: Reversing Course, E.P.A. Says Fracking Can Contaminate Drinking Water
text: WASHINGTON — The Environmental Protection Agency has concluded that hydraulic fracturing, the oil and gas extraction technique also known as fracking, has contaminated drinking water in some circumstances, according to the final version of a comprehensive study first issued in 2015.

text: Good morning.

text: To the Editor:

headline: The Top 10 Restaurant Dishes of 2016

headline: The Top 10 New York Dishes of 2016
text: A lot of the food that I transfer from fork to mouth is complicated. Some of it dazzles me, some doesn’t, and I write my reviews accordingly.

headline: The Rise of Authoritarianism
text: To the Editor:

headline: Tourism Highway Signs
text: To the Editor:

headline: Cars Talking to One Another? They Could Under Proposed Safety Rules
text: WASHINGTON — The federal government has bet on driverless vehicles as a way to reduce road fatalities. Now, it is also betting that drivers and passengers will be safer if cars can talk to one another to prevent accidents.

headline: ‘Rogue One’ Reviews: Here’s What the Critics Say
text: Movie critics got their first look at “Rogue One: A Star Wars Story” on Monday night. As their reviews spread across the internet on Tuesday, it became clear there was little consensus about the film. The reviews were mostly positive, but there were several notable exceptions.

headline: The Perfect Weapon: How Russian Cyberpower Invaded the U.S.
text: WASHINGTON — When Special Agent Adrian Hawkins of the Federal Bureau of Investigation called the Democratic National Committee in September 2015 to pass along some troubling news about its computer network, he was transferred, naturally, to the help desk.

headline: Congressional Query Into Russian Meddling Could Revive Bipartisan Oversight
text: WASHINGTON — Russian meddling in the presidential election could have one unintended but potentially positive consequence: reviving a congressional willingness to conduct serious bipartisan investigations even if they pose political risks.

headline: Minimal, Super-Functional Bags for Creatives — Designed by an Architect
text: When she started making bags last summer, the architect and designer Cece de la Montagne didn’t imagine she was founding an accessories line. She was just trying to solve a problem. Her job at a boutique SoHo-based architecture firm required her to regularly present models and large-format drawings at meetings with clients — but she couldn’t find a nice bag that could hold them without folding or wrinkling. “Not to bash Staples, but literally, the options you have are either you go to Staples or you get something really high-end,” in the $1,000-plus range, she explains. “I’d end up going to these meetings feeling like a bag lady, truthfully.”

headline: How Trump Can Avoid the Ethical Tar Pit
text: Over the years, Judicial Watch has called out many White House conflicts of interest. We fought in court against President Bill Clinton’s taking money to pay his legal bills through a legal-defense fund. During the George W. Bush administration, we questioned the propriety of his father, President George H.W. Bush, working for Carlyle Group, an investment company that was, in effect, a major defense contractor. We also investigated and sued over the connections between another defense contractor, Halliburton, and Vice President Dick Cheney, the company’s former C.E.O. We highlighted in 2014 how Bill Clinton was getting unusually large six-figure speaking fees from foreign governments while Hillary Clinton was secretary of state.

headline: What Should I Watch With My 12-Year-Old Sons?
text: Are you trying to figure out what to watch next? (Or maybe what TV show to give up on completely?) Watching is here to help. Send your questions to watching@nytimes.com.

headline: The Faces in Donald Trump’s Cabinet
text: To the Editor:

headline: At Tavo, Mexican With Stops Around the World
text: TAVO Julieta Ballesteros, who has made her name at a number of Mexican spots, including Crema, La Loteria and China Latina, has teamed up with Francisco Decrescenzo, a native of Monterrey, Mexico, and a fledgling restaurateur who developed his business plan while at the Stern School of Business at New York University. The menu’s Mexican approach is richly seasoned with global notions, the result of both partners’ travels. You will find Peking duck carnitas, chow fun noodles with corn and shrimp, and lamb chops in a chocolate-habanero sauce. Chorizo shumai, calamari in a blue cornmeal crust, and Cuban lasagna with adobo pulled pork and plantains are also available. The dining room is finished in copper, oak and white brick, and the restaurant gets its name, short for Gustavo, from one of Mr. Decrescenzo’s grandfathers. (Opens Friday): 615 Hudson Street (West 12th Street), 917-675-6454, tavonyc.com.

headline: New Rules May Curb Classroom Cupcakes
text: The season of junk-food-laden classroom holiday parties is upon us. And while some parents see all the cake, candy and salty snacks as a harmless indulgence during a festive season, others object to any unhealthy food in the classroom.

headline: 3 ISIS Terrorism Planners Killed in Syria Airstrike, Pentagon Says
text: ERBIL, Iraq — The Pentagon announced on Tuesday that a United States airstrike had killed three Islamic State operatives who were involved in mounting terrorist attacks in Europe, including the deadly assault in Paris in November 2015.

headline: Application for a Handgun
text: The application that Dylann Roof filled out to buy a Glock handgun.

headline: A Broncos Player Gets a Racist, Threatening Letter
text: This Week in Hate tracks hate crimes and harassment around the country since the election of Donald Trump. The Southern Poverty Law Center and other groups are keeping detailed counts of harassment and abuse. We will regularly present a selection of incidents to show the scope of the problem.

headline: Netflix, in Rare Cancellation, Is Ending ‘Marco Polo’
text: Here’s a rule in today’s ever-changing TV landscape: Big hits are very hard to come by.

headline: Let It Glow! With Lasers, a Holiday Home Decorating Craze Takes Off
text: Darrell Huckaby was camping last year on Jekyll Island, Ga., when he and his wife saw what he described as “thousands of lights dancing in the Spanish moss” of live oak trees. Like characters in a Spielberg film, they followed the ambient glow and were surprised to discover the source: a small box stuck in the ground.

headline: ‘Pet City’ Columnist Reflects: Dying — It’s What Pets Do
text: Times Insider delivers behind-the-scenes insights from The New York Times. In this piece, our Pet City columnist shares his own personal tales of love and loss.

headline: Under Rex Tillerson, Exxon Mobil Forged Its Own Path Abroad
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Struggling to keep Iraq from splintering, American diplomats pushed for a law in 2011 to share the country’s oil wealth among its fractious regions.

headline: Protesters Sing Polish National Anthem
text: Crowds gathered in Warsaw on Tuesday night to demonstrate against Poland's governing party's decision to restrict public gatherings by singing the country's national anthem.

headline: A Gingerbread City Guards Its Secrets
text: TORUN, Poland — This medieval city on the banks of the Vistula River is known for two things: the astronomer Nicolaus Copernicus and gingerbread cookies.

headline: Big Banks Fight to Block Crisis-Era Lawsuits From Continuing
text: Big banks are fighting tens of billions of dollars of potential legal costs linked to at least a dozen pending lawsuits arising from the financial crisis. Now they want the Supreme Court to weigh in, arguing that regulators took too long to file their claims.

headline: Aleppo Activists Say Final Goodbyes as Assad Closes In
text: Syrian government forces had reclaimed most of rebel-held eastern Aleppo by Tuesday, in a fierce battle. Activists and civilians in the last opposition-controlled areas posted videos describing their fear.

headline: The Gingerbread of Torun, Poland
text: A spicy cookie from the Middle Ages continues to draw visitors to this medieval city.

headline: E. R. Braithwaite, Author of ‘To Sir, With Love,’ Dies at 104
text: E. R. Braithwaite, a Guyanese author, diplomat and former Royal Air Force pilot whose book “To Sir, With Love,” a memoir of teaching in London’s deprived East End, was adapted into a hit 1967 film starring Sidney Poitier, died on Monday in Rockville, Md. He was 104.

headline: Fox Faces New Lawsuit Claiming Harassment by Roger Ailes
text: Nearly five months after Roger Ailes was ousted from his position as chairman of Fox News Channel, the sexual harassment accusations against him continue.

headline: For This Choreographer, Dance Speaks Truer Than Words
text: “I hate the written word,” the choreographer Reggie Wilson said with an almost wicked edge, as he sat in his cozy kitchen in Brooklyn, drinking sweet tea on a recent blustery day. Then, acknowledging my confusion, he added, “Now breathe, breathe.”

headline: Editors’ Note
text: Times editors have removed this document.

headline: Shirley Hazzard, Novelist Who Charted Storm-Tossed Lives, Dies at 85
text: Shirley Hazzard, the Australian-born author of an acclaimed if small portfolio of fiction peopled with characters whose lives, much like her own, toss them up far from home, died on Monday night at her home in Manhattan. She was 85.

headline: For Maren Morris, the Year Everything Came Together
text: In between being nominated for four Grammy Awards and performing as the musical guest on “Saturday Night Live” last week, the 26-year-old country singer Maren Morris had work to do.

headline: Excerpt: ‘Nabucco’
text: The Metropolitan Opera Opera chorus sings “Va, pensiero” from Act III of Verdi’s “Nabucco.”

headline: Review: James Levine and Plácido Domingo, Storming the Met Anew
text: There is a party going on at the Metropolitan Opera House, and if you are a fan of the raucous, eccentric, solemn, hilarious and heartbreaking art form that’s celebrated there, you should join the fun before it ends on Jan. 7.

headline: Stein Ends Recount Bid, but Says It Revealed Flaws in Voting System
text: Jill Stein, the Green Party presidential candidate, on Tuesday closed her long-shot bid to recount the votes in three battleground states, saying that the effort encountered bureaucratic hurdles and revealed deep shortcomings in the elections system.

headline: It’s a Blizzard Onstage. Here’s All the Dirt.
text: The tree has grown to its full height, and the Mouse King has suffered a sound defeat. In “Nutcracker” terms, that means the wondrous Waltz of the Snowflakes is just around the corner.

headline: Santas, Wreaths and So Many Lights: Holiday Cheer Around New York
text: T sent two photographers to document the city in the weeks before Christmas. What they captured was particularly festive.

headline: Review: ‘Table Manners,’ Chef Jeremiah Tower’s Guide for All Dining Challenges
text: We no-nonsense Americans have long sneered at fussy Old World etiquette. One senator’s account of a meal with George Washington during his presidency included this observation: “At every interval of eating or drinking he played on the table with a fork or knife, like a drumstick.”

headline: Trump Is Said to Offer Interior Job to Ryan Zinke, Montana Lawmaker
text: WASHINGTON — President-elect Donald J. Trump has offered the position of secretary of the interior to Montana’s freshman representative, Ryan Zinke, a former Navy SEAL commander, two officials familiar with Mr. Trump’s decision confirmed on Tuesday.

headline: What We’re Reading
text: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What We’re Reading emails are sent twice a week. Sign up »

headline: Daughter of Suspect in Patz Murder Testifies Through Tears
text: She watched along with a courtroom of strangers as prosecutors played a video of her 16th birthday party, showing a joyful moment of her in a white dress and dancing with her father. She was shown a video of a baptism party for her mother’s goddaughter and photographs taken inside the modest brown house in Maple Shade, N.J., where she had lived with her parents.

headline: John Kasich Signs One Abortion Bill in Ohio but Vetoes a More Restrictive Measure
text: WASHINGTON — Gov. John Kasich of Ohio on Tuesday signed into law a ban on abortion after 20 weeks of pregnancy, but vetoed a far more restrictive measure that would have barred abortions after a fetal heartbeat was detected, as early as six weeks into a pregnancy.

headline: Bryan Cranston, Megan Mullally and Zoey Deutch at ‘Why Him?’ Screening
text: The stars of the holiday comedy film, “Why Him?” attend a screening at new iPic Theater.

headline: Review: Goodbye to Giraffe Meat in ‘Ghostland’
text: “Please let us kill this giraffe,” a Ju/’hoansi tribesman entreats during a tour of the Kalahari desert in northern Namibia in “Ghostland: The View of the Ju/’hoansi.” Young giraffes “have very soft meat,” another tribe member enthuses.

headline: Bryan Cranston, Megan Mullally and Zoey Deutch at the ‘Why Him?’ Screening
text: “Oh, this is going to be an Academy picture,” Bryan Cranston joked on Sunday night. “I guarantee it.”

headline: Review: A Chaotic Universe in ‘Star’
text: “Star,” Lee Daniels’s new musical fantasy series for Fox, stars the relatively unknown Jude Demorest as a young woman named Star who wants to be a star. Subtlety is not its strong point.

headline: Rick Perry Is the Wrong Choice for Energy Secretary
text: Much has been made of the irony of Rick Perry’s nomination to be the next secretary of energy. He would oversee a department that he wanted to eliminate as a Republican presidential candidate in the 2012 primaries, though he couldn’t remember its name during a debate.

text: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Protests Erupt in Poland Over New Law on Public Gatherings
text: WARSAW — When supporters of Poland’s governing party met for their monthly gathering last weekend outside the presidential palace to commemorate the 2010  plane crash that killed many of the country’s top leaders, they found that a group of protesters had already commandeered their usual spot.

headline: Being ‘Fleabag,’ From Stage to TV and Back Again
text: LONDON — Within five minutes of the first episode of “Fleabag,” Phoebe Waller-Bridge is masturbating over President Obama. As he gives a speech on her laptop, her right hand drifts down under the duvet. “There will be difficult days along the way,” Mr. Obama warns. The screen starts to jiggle.

headline: A Potential Hitch in Zuckerberg’s Stock Plan for Facebook
text: Mark Zuckerberg wants to give away nearly all his stake in Facebook, and yet still keep control of the company he helped found. What’s a tech billionaire to do?

headline: The Best Sellers: Filed Under Sports
text: The best-selling sports books in November 2016, according to the New York Times best-seller list.

headline: Wells Fargo’s ‘Living Will’ Plan Is Rejected Again by Regulators
text: Wells Fargo has run afoul of banking regulators once again: On Tuesday, for the second time this year, the bank did not pass a key regulatory test that was created after the 2008 financial crisis to reduce the threats that large banks pose to the broader economy.

headline: Court Debates Which Cosby Accusers May Testify
text: NORRISTOWN, PA. — A prosecutor on Tuesday accused Bill Cosby of drugging and assaulting 13 women over several decades in a pattern of behavior so similar that he said it should be admitted as evidence in Mr. Cosby’s criminal trial for sexual assault.

headline: An N.F.L. Executive, Honoring His Lost Sister, Speaks Out About Anorexia
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Paraag Marathe’s structured, analytical mind has served him well in the offices of Silicon Valley and the National Football League. He figured that he could lean on those traits the first time he spoke publicly about his sister, Shilpa, and how anorexia had taken her life.

headline: New York Changes the Way It Keeps Tabs on School Violence
text: New York State education officials voted Tuesday to change the way the state tracks school violence, hoping to improve a system that has been called confusing and inaccurate.

headline: Will Rick Perry Be the Energy Department’s Undoing?
text: President-elect Donald Trump has picked several people to lead federal departments who are hostile to the work of those agencies. On Tuesday, he went a step further by choosing Rick Perry, the former Texas governor, to head the Department of Energy, an agency that Mr. Perry once promised to eliminate.

headline: Mired in 16-Year Title Drought, U.S. Fed Cup Team Turns to a New Captain
text: Despite Serena Williams’s domination of the women’s tennis tour, and with 16 players in the top 100, the United States has a 16-year title drought in the Fed Cup, an international team competition it once dominated.

headline: Letting Go of a Red Balloon
text: Dear Diary:

headline: The D.C.C.C. Responds to the Hack
text: Letters from Democratic Party leaders responding to the cyberattack on servers of the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee and the subsequent release of personal and professional information of lawmakers and staff members.

headline: Democratic House Candidates Were Also Targets of Russian Hacking
text: WASHINGTON — South Florida has long been a laboratory for some of the nation’s roughest politics, with techniques like phantom candidates created by political rivals to siphon off votes from their opponents, or so-called boleteras hired to illegally fill out stacks of absentee ballots on behalf of elderly or disabled voters.

headline: Pageant Silences Beauty Queen, a Critic of China, at U.S. Contest
text: After the Chinese authorities blocked the Canadian beauty queen Anastasia Lin from attending the 65th annual Miss World pageant in China last year, the event’s British organizers offered her a consolation prize, of sorts: They promised to allow her a chance to compete in the 2016 finals, which are currently underway in suburban Washington.

headline: Recreational Marijuana? Yes, but Tightly Regulated, Canadian Panel Suggests
text: MONTREAL — Prime Minister Justin Trudeau has promised to legalize the recreational use of marijuana, but that doesn’t mean Canada will turn into a giant, smoke-filled set for a Cheech and Chong movie.

headline: Thomas C. Schelling, Master Theorist of Nuclear Strategy, Dies at 95
text: Thomas C. Schelling, an economist and Nobel laureate whose interest in game theory led him to write important works on nuclear strategy and to use the concept of the tipping point to explain social problems, including white flight from urban neighborhoods, died on Tuesday at his home in Bethesda, Md. He was 95.

headline: ‘We Are the Sport of Jackie Robinson, and We Need to Lead by Example’
text: A little over a year ago, Billy Bean, Major League Baseball’s ambassador for inclusion, began hearing from people outside the sport who were concerned about a growing phenomenon inside the game.

headline: Rolling Back Abortion Rights After Donald Trump’s Election
text: Last year, Teresa Fedor, an Ohio state representative, a veteran and a former public-school teacher, told the story of her abortion after a rape in a statement on the House floor. “I dare you to walk in my shoes,” she said to lawmakers who were supporting a bill to ban abortion as soon as a fetal heartbeat could be detected, as early as six weeks. “I understand your story, but you don’t understand mine.”

headline: 10 New York Sites Get Landmark Status as Panel Clears Backlog
text: It has taken more than two years to resolve the bureaucratic quagmire of backlogged buildings at the New York City Landmarks Preservation Commission. Considering that some have been in limbo for four decades, it may have seemed like no time at all.

headline: Facing Athletes’ Boycott, Bobsled and Skeleton Event Is Moved From Russia
text: International sports officials, facing a potential boycott by athletes upset over the Russian doping scandal, have decided to move bobsled and skeleton world championships out of Russia next year.

headline: With Second Ave. Subway, Cuomo Has Hands-On Role and Eye on the Future
text: As governor of New York, Andrew M. Cuomo has no shortage of complex problems demanding his attention. But his ire has recently been focused on a small switch in a subway station deep below the streets of Manhattan.

headline: ISIS Claims Responsibility for Egypt Church Bombing and Warns of More to Come
text: CAIRO — Egypt faced the prospect of a surge in sectarian bloodshed on Tuesday after the Islamic State claimed responsibility for the bombing of a Coptic cathedral in Cairo that killed 25 people on Sunday. The group warned of more attacks to come.

headline: Rex Tillerson, Trump’s Secretary of State Nominee, Is a Flexible Pragmatist
text: HOUSTON — Three years ago, Rex W. Tillerson, the chief executive of Exxon Mobil and now President-elect Donald J. Trump’s nominee for secretary of state, was probably the man least expected to show up at a town council meeting in North Texas to oppose a local construction project.

headline: Extensive Brain Defects Seen in Babies of Mothers With Zika
text: Babies born to Zika-infected mothers are highly likely to have brain damage, even in the absence of obvious abnormalities like small heads, and the virus may go on replicating in their brains well after birth, according to three studies published Tuesday.

headline: Large Military Plane Over Manhattan Turns Heads Skyward
text: For New Yorkers accustomed to staring straight ahead and avoiding eye contact with their fellow pedestrians, the appearance on Tuesday afternoon of a large military airplane and two helicopters over Manhattan was cause for confusion and craning upward.

headline: U.S. Blocks Arms Sale to Saudi Arabia Amid Concerns Over Yemen War
text: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration has deepened its rift with its Gulf allies over the ongoing conflict in Yemen, blocking a transfer of precision munitions to Saudi Arabia because of concerns about civilian casualties that administration officials attribute to poor targeting.

headline: State Orders Monitor for New York City’s Child Welfare Agency
text: The state has ordered New York City to install an independent monitor to review the city’s troubled child welfare agency, the latest fallout from the recent deaths of children who had been the subjects of abuse reports to the agency.

headline: Review: The Devil Went Down to Chelsea to See ‘Prudencia Hart’
text: In search of merry and bright drinking companions in this dark and sullen winter? You could do a lot worse than raise a shot glass (or two or three) with the rousing band of Scots who’ve encamped in a pub at the McKittrick Hotel in Chelsea. They sing, dance on tables, discuss post-post-structuralist theory, talk in rhyme. And they tell one hell of a tale.

headline: Something to Follow
text: WEDNESDAY PUZZLE — Are you a leader or a follower? Never mind, it doesn’t matter. We are all following things in today’s New York Times debut by Alan DeLoriea. No cutting in line, please.

headline: Judge May Make Public Some Documents Related to Inquiry on Clinton Emails
text: A federal judge in Manhattan indicated on Tuesday that he may partially unseal a government search warrant and supporting documents stemming from the F.B.I.’s investigation of a large cache of emails belonging to Huma Abedin, a top aide to Hillary Clinton.

headline: Bob Krasnow, Revitalizer of Elektra Records, Dies at 82
text: Bob Krasnow, a well-traveled music executive credited with revitalizing Elektra Records in the 1980s and ’90s with a varied roster that included Metallica, Anita Baker and Björk, died on Dec. 11 in Wellington, Fla. He was 82.

headline: Behind Brooklyn Neighborhood’s Rebirth, a Woman Who Joined in a Dream
text: The car coasted down her sister’s old block in Brownsville, Brooklyn, and in the front seat Janis Borden glanced out the window and, for an instant, saw not a Monday in December 2016, but an evening in the late 1970s or early 1980s. At the time, Ms. Borden’s sister, Carmelia Goffe, had three little sons.

headline: From Kanye West to the Midwest, Donald Trump’s Presidential Reality Show Rolls On
text: WEST ALLIS, Wis. — President-elect Donald J. Trump said on Tuesday that his nominee for secretary of state, Rex W. Tillerson, would reverse “years of foreign policy blunders and disasters,” and that his close ties to antagonistic foreign leaders — a potential hurdle to his confirmation by the Senate — was one of the reasons he had picked him.

headline: Protests Erupt Across Brazil as Senate Approves Austerity Measure
text: RIO DE JANEIRO — Protests flared in cities around Brazil on Tuesday after the Senate approved a 20-year cap on federal spending, a cornerstone of President Michel Temer’s proposed austerity measures aimed at restoring confidence in the country’s ailing economy.

headline: Quotation of the Day
text: “This was not something that was done casually, this was not something that was done by chance, this was not a target that was selected purely arbitrarily.”

headline: Blackhawks Cool Off Rangers and Backup Goalie Antti Raanta
text: There is invariably extra electricity when the Rangers and the Blackhawks meet, especially since they play each other only twice a season.

headline: For Taiwan, a Dilemma Over Identity, Economy and China
text: Syaru Shirley Lin, a native of Taiwan, is a political economist who teaches at both the University of Virginia and the Chinese University of Hong Kong. Previously she was a partner at Goldman Sachs, where she was responsible for private equity and venture capital investments in Asia and spearheaded the firm’s investments in technology start-ups, including Alibaba. Her new book, “Taiwan’s China Dilemma,” published by Stanford University Press, focuses on the emergence of Taiwanese national identity and how it has influenced the island’s economic policy toward China over the past three decades.

headline: K.K.R.-Linked Group Bids for Tatts of Australia, Imperiling Tabcorp Deal
text: HONG KONG — Wall Street money is helping fuel a potential bidding war over gambling in Australia.

headline: Alan Thicke, Reassuring Father on ‘Growing Pains,’ Dies at 69
text: Alan Thicke, the Canadian actor, singer and songwriter best remembered for his portrayal of the ultimate suburban middlebrow dispenser of parental advice on the sitcom “Growing Pains,” died on Tuesday in Burbank, Calif. He was 69.

headline: What Do Teenagers Want? Potted Plant Parents
text: Many parents feel that their adolescents hardly need them anymore. Teenagers often come and go on their own schedules, sometimes rebuff our friendly questions about their days, and can give the impression that interacting with the family is an imposition that comes at the cost of connecting, digitally or otherwise, with friends.

headline: On a Japanese Whiskey Tour, Small Batches and Bagpipes
text: One of the many discoveries I made on my first night in Japan nearly 30 years ago were the vending machines that sold beer. As I walked to my new apartment just hours after landing in Tokyo, I found a machine stocked with different sizes of cans and brands. It was a eureka moment.

headline: Aleppo, Rex Tillerson, Donald Trump: Your Wednesday Briefing
text: Good morning.

headline: Argentine Firm to Pay $112 Million in FIFA Scandal
text: An Argentine sports marketing firm will pay more than $112 million in forfeiture and fines in the FIFA bribery scandal.

text: FRONT PAGE

headline: What’s on TV Wednesday: Series Finale of ‘Rectify’ and a Preview of ‘Star’
text: “Rectify,” the Peabody Award-winning series about the release and redemption of a death row prisoner, ends. “Star,” the latest creation from Lee Daniels of “Empire” fame, has a preview. And a new season of the French smash “The Bureau” crosses the Atlantic.

headline: Kylie Jenner and the Year of the Drop
text: Last Friday, on a sunny December morning, chaos descended upon a glossy shopping mall in the Canoga Park section of Los Angeles.
