text: New picture books include “The Wish Tree” and “The Great Spruce.”

headline: A Prison Class in African Religion Attracts Students Beyond Its Walls
text: BEDFORD HILLS, N.Y. — In many ways, the class that met here Tuesday night could be in any university in the United States. There were desks arranged in a circle to facilitate discussion. There were student presentations based on dense readings. And there was the faint buzzing from the fluorescent lights overhead.

headline: Mayor Shakes Up Media Operation Again
text: The de Blasio administration announced on Friday it had hired a former spokesman for Bernie Sanders to run its day-to-day media strategy.

headline: Challah
text: Challah bread is delicious fresh out of the oven, but it gets even better with the addition of orange juice and olive oil.

headline: Five Steadicam Milestones
text: A look at the camera operating system that made “The Shining,” “Rocky” and “Goodfellas” possible.

headline: The Invention That Shot Rocky Up Those Steps
text: After scouting locations for “Rocky,” the director John G. Avildsen still had no idea how to pull off a crucial scene. Then his assistant cameraman invited him to view a demonstration reel for a new piece of equipment. It included a shot of the inventor’s girlfriend running up the stairs of the Philadelphia Museum of Art. “And I said, ‘Hmm, I know just where that’s going to go,’” Mr. Avildsen recalled.

headline: ‘Walking Dead’ Finale Falls to 15.2 Million Viewers
text: The midseason finale of AMC’s “The Walking Dead” had 15.2 million viewers, a drop of about three million from last year’s equivalent episode, according to data from Nielsen that includes live watching and three days of delayed viewing.

headline: Paperback Row
text: Seven new paperbacks to check out this week.

headline: How Streaming, Exclusives and the Chainsmokers Made 2016 a Disruptive Year for Pop
text: Last week on the Popcast, the New York Times pop team started to analyze what critic Jon Caramanica calls “a disruptive year in the pop music ecosystem” via the best albums of the year — powerful releases by some of the country’s most prodigious talents, including Beyoncé, Frank Ocean and Bon Iver. In each of those cases, the album was an evolutionary step for the artist in question, and also for pop music more broadly.

headline: With Peter Evans on Trumpet, Only the Shape Is Familiar
text: Peter Evans brought a piccolo trumpet to his lips at the start of a recent solo performance at Pioneer Works in Brooklyn, and within moments he’d cast a deep and disorienting spell. Standing on the concrete floor in semidarkness, he played one long, unbroken improvisation that defied the conventional limitations of the instrument, if not the laws of physics.

headline: Are Americans Experiencing Collective Trauma?
text: We’re all familiar with the notion of psychological trauma — damage to an individual’s psyche caused by an extremely distressing event. But there’s also another kind of trauma: a collective disturbance that happens to a group of people when their world is suddenly upended.

headline: Germany Investigates if Boy, 12, Planted Bomb at Christmas Market
text: BERLIN — The authorities are investigating whether a 12-year-old boy made a bomb and planted it at a traditional Christmas market in his hometown in southwestern Germany.

headline: How to Braid Challah Bread
text: Learn how to make an elegant lattice braid challah round.

headline: Saturday’s N.F.L. Matchup: Miami Dolphins (8-5) at Jets (4-9)
text: 8:25 p.m. Line: Dolphins by 2½

headline: The Golden Secret to Better Challah
text: Over the last decade, bakers have been experimenting with olive oil in all kinds of nontraditional ways, and I’ve been right there with them. I’ve added it to cakes, swirled it into lemon bars, even baked it into zucchini bread — all to the good.

headline: Peanut Butter, Jelly and Racism
text: What is implicit bias? NYT/POV's Saleem Reshamwala unscrews the lid on the unfair effects of our subconscious.

headline: In Montreal, an Ungainly and Unloved Christmas Tree
text: MONTREAL — The idea was to celebrate Montreal’s coming 375th anniversary with a Christmas tree bigger and grander than the famous one at Rockefeller Center in New York.

headline: California Employee Pension Will Consider Cutting Return Assumption
text: Calpers may be getting a bit more real. The $300 billion California public employees’ pension manager is considering cutting its investment return assumption. The move would squeeze the budgets of public authorities and employees, but secure funding for retirees. If the American government pension bellwether can do it, others will follow.

headline: Check Our Bias to Wreck Our Bias
text: Signs of implicit bias lurk within our inboxes, social networks and the patterns of our daily lives. Looking at our own data can help us change our ways.

headline: The Life-Changing Magic of Hanging Out
text: To reduce implicit bias, build friendships that cross the racial divide. Sound too easy to actually work? Researchers beg to differ.

headline: Why We’re Awkward
text: Here’s a paradox: The harder we try to act “super normal” around people of other races, the more likely we’ll be super weird. Is there a way around this? Hint: Yes.

headline: Snacks and Punishment
text: Need justification for taking breaks and naps? Turns out those activities could make us less biased toward people of other races.

headline: High Heels, Violins and a Warning
text: Orchestras made clever changes to deal with centuries-old bias. If an orchestra can do it, there's hope for all of us — but a final word of caution.

headline: Wedged and Softened to Fit in on the Upper West Side
text: Bordered by two of the city’s largest parks, with some of its best schools and a wealth of good transportation options, homes on the Upper West Side are typically in high demand. The only thing missing — at least in the eyes of developers — has been land to build on.

headline: A ‘Daily Show’ Correspondent Adjusts to Life in New York
text: When the actor and comedian Hasan Minhaj was hired as a correspondent on “The Daily Show” in late 2014, the new job meant moving from Los Angeles to New York, where he and his wife, Beena, live in a sleek one-bedroom rental in Hell’s Kitchen. It also meant the purchase of wholly unfamiliar clothing.

headline: The Humiliations of Life After Congress
text: Washington — Once, I occupied a prized office in the Rayburn House Office Building, with a commanding view that stretched to the Lincoln Memorial. Now, I occupy Cubicle No. 45, with a decent view of Cubicles 44 and 46.

headline: Donald Trump’s Israel Ambassador Pick Is Hazardous to Peace
text: PRINCETON, N.J. — President-elect Donald J. Trump’s selection of David Friedman as United States ambassador to Israel is a serious mistake that should be rectified. Spoken and published statements by Mr. Friedman, a 57-year-old bankruptcy lawyer in New York, about Israel and American policies in the Mideast suggest he is unsuitable to represent America in one of the most high-pressure diplomatic positions in the world. This call to withdraw Mr. Friedman’s name also reflects a sober assessment of the damage that could be caused to American interests and to Mr. Trump’s presidency by the reckless words for which Mr. Friedman is already known.

headline: Obama Says He Told Putin: ‘Cut It Out’ on Hacking
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama said for the first time on Friday that he had held back from retaliating against Russia’s meddling in the presidential race for fear of inciting further hacking “that could hamper vote counting.” But he said he was weighing a mix of public and covert actions against the Russians in his last 34 days in office, actions that would increase “the costs for them.”

headline: Visualizing the Invisible Drivers of Climate Change
text: This new visualization from NASA shows how carbon dioxide dances in the atmosphere.

headline: Review: Michael Feinstein’s Holiday Ode to Judy Garland
text: There were no jingling bells, Santa hats or signs of giddy festivity at the opening-night performance of Michael Feinstein’s show, “A Holiday to Remember,” at Feinstein’s/54 Below. This was the most sober evening of seasonal cheer I can recall in the singer’s long-running tradition of annual Christmastime fetes, which in earlier days evoked the glossy bonhomie of TV variety specials.

headline: Ex-N.H.L. Enforcer Moves to Hong Kong and Shows His Nurturing Side
text: HONG KONG — Taking the ice here on a recent weekday evening, Barry Beck issued an unsubtle warning to a fellow skater who had come to play hockey without neck protection.

headline: In Shadow of Amazon, European Challenger Looks to China for Inspiration
text: BERLIN — Robert Gentz stepped off an Air Berlin plane in Beijing with the goal of conquering online fashion in China. By the time he boarded his return flight to Berlin, he had a new plan: to copy it.

headline: How Much Watching Time Do You Have This Weekend?
text: No matter how much free time you have this weekend, we have TV recommendations for you. Come back every Friday for new suggestions from our TV critic on what to watch.

headline: ‘I Cannot Lie,’ Rodrigo Duterte Says, Confirming He Did Kill People as Mayor
text: President Rodrigo Duterte of the Philippines confirmed on Friday that he had personally pulled the trigger and killed three people as mayor of Davao City, doubling down on boastful comments he made this week, which loyalists had tried to deny.

headline: The Succulent Short Rib Upends the Roast
text: A giant beef roast for the holidays is, for many, de rigueur. Standing rib roast with all the trimmings signifies extravagance, luxury and abundance.

headline: Christian Gerhaher
text: Excerpt from “Wo die schönen Trompeten blasen”

headline: Canada Today: Energy Project Clash, Christmas Tree Scorn and Rules on Marijuana
text: The expansion of the Trans Mountain pipeline is not the only energy mega-project attracting protests in British Columbia. Our Dan Levin went to the Peace River Valley, where the provincially owned electrical utility in British Columbia plans to spend $7 billion to build a dam and flood about 51 miles of the valley within the decade. The project has raised environmental concerns and has been challenged on constitutional grounds by indigenous groups. But Mr. Levin also found that many people also think the dam, known as Site C, makes no sense when electrical demand is flat and alternative power sources are increasingly feeding the grid.

headline: A Diva, Two Pianists and a Pair of ‘Messiahs’: Classical Music This Week
text: We’re happy to introduce a new weekly roundup of classical music coverage, appearing in print every Saturday.

headline: North Carolina Governor Signs Law Limiting Successor’s Power
text: RALEIGH, N.C. — Amid a tense and dramatic backdrop of outrage and frustration, North Carolina’s Republican-controlled legislature on Friday approved a sweeping package of restrictions on the power of the governor’s office in advance of the swearing in of the Democratic governor-elect, Roy Cooper.

headline: What We’re Reading
text: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What We’re Reading emails are sent twice a week. Sign up »

headline: Christian Gerhaher: Summiting Mount Mahler
text: The German baritone Christian Gerhaher is the foremost lieder, or art song, singer of our time, able to blend poetic intelligence with endless shadings of vocal color. On Saturday, he returns to Lincoln Center, accompanied by his longtime friend and pianist Gerold Huber. Asked to choose a favorite page from this all-Mahler recital, Mr. Gerhaher selected one that’s special not just for what it says about Mahler but about the art of song more generally.

headline: Bill Cunningham, Unpublished Photos
text: Every Sunday, after Bill had gone to church, I could be sure that my phone would ring. “Kurdewan … Bill Cunningham here,” he would say, as if I didn’t know, every time. Every week we would talk about his pages “On the Street” and “Evening Hours,” and he was always very concerned about whether the reader was getting bored with them. It always amazed me that he would even think that. And every Sunday we would start planning our course for the next week, like how many parties he had to go to (sometimes it was 15 or 16) and which charities he wanted to cover. I would tell him he had to start slowing down, but, of course, he never listened.

headline: When a Writing Opportunity Knocks, Answer
text: After graduate school, I moved back to Boston, where I’d spent my undergraduate years. I’d just earned a master’s degree in creative writing from Stanford University and was pumped with literary ambition.

headline: The Fight for Falluja
text: Embed with Iraqi forces as they retake a city from ISIS – and experience the battle's aftermath.

headline: Wall Street’s Annual Stock Forecasts: Bullish, and Often Wrong
text: Don’t expect Wall Street investment houses to predict a stock market decline in 2017. That’s just not what they usually do.

headline: Obama, Aleppo, Vladimir Putin: Your Friday Evening Briefing
text: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: ‘Respect the Feathers’: Who Tells Standing Rock’s Story?
text: As the Standing Rock protest against the Dakota Access Pipeline has gone from bad to worse to hopeful to tentative, dozens of documentarians have descended on the Sioux reservation — 34 teams, according to the tribal database. And while it’s no longer uncommon for major news events to attract multiple filmmakers, some members of the horde in North Dakota seemed to need a lesson in where they were.

headline: Whistle-Blowers Spur Companies to Change Their Ways
text: For those who doubt that whistle-blowers are a force for good in corporate America — and yes, such skeptics exist — a new study out of the University of Iowa could not be more important. It demonstrates for the first time that financial shenanigans at companies decrease markedly in the years after truth tellers come forward with information about wrongdoing inside their operations.

headline: New York City to Close ‘Persistently Struggling’ School in the South Bronx
text: The New York City Education Department said on Friday that it planned to close Junior High School 162 Lola Rodriguez de Tio in the South Bronx, which has been among the lowest-performing schools in New York State for a decade.

headline: Look Who’s Talking: The Previously Silent Conn’s
text: Remember Conn’s? It’s the appliance and furniture chain, based in Texas, that refused to speak to the Haggler when, in the summer of 2014, he tried to intervene on behalf of an unhappy customer.

headline: In Kayak Death Case, Jury Will See Police Interrogation Video
text: GOSHEN, N.Y. — The judge in the case of a woman accused of killing her fiancé during a kayak outing will allow jurors to watch virtually all of an 11-hour police interrogation video in which the defendant, Angelika Graswald, makes a series of incriminating statements.

headline: Assad’s Lesson From Aleppo: Force Works, With Few Consequences
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — For months, the bodies have been piling up in eastern Aleppo as the buildings have come down, pulverized by Syrian and Russian jets, burying residents who could not flee in avalanches of bricks and mortar.

headline: Trump Picks Mick Mulvaney, South Carolina Congressman, as Budget Director
text: WASHINGTON — President-elect Donald J. Trump has selected Representative Mick Mulvaney of South Carolina, a conservative Republican member of the House and a fierce advocate of deep spending cuts, to be his budget director.

headline: Vine, the Six-Second Video App, Is Not Quite Shutting Down
text: Vine has died. Vine has risen again.

headline: Prosecutors Drop Inquiry Into Charles Hynes, Former Brooklyn District Attorney
text: Prosecutors said on Friday that they had dropped their long-running criminal investigation into whether Charles J. Hynes, the former Brooklyn district attorney, misused public money in his unsuccessful 2013 re-election campaign.

headline: Larry Colburn, Who Helped Stop My Lai Massacre, Dies at 67
text: Larry Colburn, who became an 18-year-old American hero when he intervened with two comrades to halt the massacre of unarmed Vietnamese civilians by United States soldiers in 1968, elevating an innocuous hamlet named My Lai into a watchword for the horrors of war, died on Tuesday at his home in Canton, Ga. He was 67.

headline: De Blasio Insists His Administration Will Be Cleared in Fund-Raising Inquiries
text: As federal and state grand juries hear evidence about his political fund-raising, Mayor Bill de Blasio on Friday said he was confident that his administration would be found to have done nothing wrong.

headline: Auction Offering Coffee With Ivanka Trump Is Canceled
text: WASHINGTON — An auction offering a 45-minute private meeting with Ivanka Trump in exchange for a charitable donation was abruptly canceled Friday after questions were raised about the process by ethics experts, who said it appeared to offer bidders special access to the next first family.

headline: Women’s Cricket Gains in Numbers and Visibility, but Gender Gaps Remain
text: As in most sports, women’s cricket has long been overshadowed by the men’s game, but there are signs that that is changing.

headline: Trump May Stay at His Hotel, Not Blair House, Before Inauguration
text: WASHINGTON — President-elect Donald J. Trump is considering spending his last nights as a private citizen ensconced in his new Washington hotel, rather than at Blair House as many of his predecessors have, according to people briefed on the planning.

headline: Venezuela Voids Popular Form of Currency, Setting Off Panic
text: CARACAS, Venezuela — Carrying trash bags and backpacks filled with cash, Venezuelans fretfully lined up on Friday outside banks across the country to exchange currency that President Nicolás Maduro said would soon be void.

headline: Russia’s Hacks Followed Years of Paranoia Toward Hillary Clinton
text: Russia’s unprecedented intervention in the United States election came amid more than United States-Russia tension and Donald J. Trump’s praise of Vladimir V. Putin, the Russian president. It also coincided with a growing belief, in Moscow, that Russia faced an imminent threat in Hillary Clinton’s candidacy.

headline: Women Make Up Majority of U.S. Law Students for First Time
text: For the first time, women make up a majority of law students, holding just over 50 percent of the seats at accredited law schools in the United States.

headline: What? No Viagra Bowl? Not Yet, Anyway
text: Things you’ve never heard:

headline: The Man Who Gave an Android His Best Lines in the ‘Star Wars’ Film ‘Rogue One’
text: You may not have seen much of the actor Alan Tudyk’s face, but if you’ve been watching Disney movies lately, you’ve heard a lot of his voice. He has been behind characters in “Wreck-It Ralph,” “Frozen,” “Big Hero Six,” “Zootopia” and “Moana.”

headline: Aroldis Chapman Says Joe Maddon Overused Him in Cubs’ Title Run
text: If Manager Joe Girardi’s ironclad, by-the-book protocol leaves some Yankees fans gnashing their teeth from time to time, it feels like a security blanket to Aroldis Chapman.

headline: Agony as Tulane Applicants Learn Acceptance Emails Are in Error
text: Alyssa was in her high school health class around midday Wednesday when she got the email welcoming her to Tulane University and giving her a college email address. In a grueling college admissions season, it was her first-choice university, and she had applied early decision, meaning she was committed to the place.

headline: University of Minnesota and Football Players Met Over Boycott
text: The University of Minnesota’s president met with the football team late Friday, a day after the players had pledged to boycott a bowl game unless the university lifted the suspensions of 10 teammates related to a sexual assault investigation.

headline: Quotation of the Day
text: “We are well beyond normal political concerns here. This is about the integrity of our democracy and the security of our nation.”

headline: Sticky Notes Bearing Election Hopes and Fears Removed from Subway
text: The thousands of sticky notes lining a subway station wall in Manhattan bearing messages about the 2016 presidential race came down on Friday, marking the end of one of the most significant public expressions of emotion in response to the election results.

headline: Uber Defies California Regulators With Self-Driving Car Service
text: For seven years, Uber’s stance on complying with regulations has been consistent: Ask forgiveness, not permission.

headline: Buyer Beware: ‘Certified’ Used Cars May Still Be Under Recall
text: The public has long been wary of used cars and the claims of roadworthiness by the dealers who sell them. On Friday, the nation’s main advertising regulator issued a ruling that consumer groups complained will give used-car dealers too much leeway in the disclosures they are required to make.

headline: Cold Advice: Layer Up, Get Below Ground ... or Embrace It
text: From Vermont to Chicago, the first Arctic blast of the winter sent temperatures and wind chills, in some places, below zero. Staying warm depends on where one is.

headline: McConnell Eyed Ryan Zinke for a Senate Seat. Donald Trump Had Other Ideas.
text: WASHINGTON — The courtship of Ryan Zinke began months before the end of the presidential race. A Republican congressman from Montana and a former Navy SEAL commander, Mr. Zinke was approached over the summer by Senator Mitch McConnell, the majority leader, about running for the Senate in 2018.

headline: At Elite Queens High School, PTA Calls Embattled Principal ‘Rude’
text: Townsend Harris High School is one of New York City’s most prestigious public schools, where 100 percent of students graduate on time and all of them are prepared for college, according to city metrics.

headline: 6,000 Miles on a Shopping Bike
text: London — Every bike ride is a pocket drama. Reflect on the humblest cycling commute and you’ll find yourself reliving short-story excitements denied to co-workers who yawned their way in on the train: the reconstructive surgery so skilfully swerved when some idiot flung open his car door, the race you pretended not to have with that courier, those bracing exchanges with bike-blind jaywalkers and cabdrivers.

headline: Corrections: December 17, 2016
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: Trump and Putin, in the Barn
text: I was raised in an era when we spent a lot of time worrying about Russia. That was because of Communism, which was such an obsession in my Catholic school that the countries on the map were colored red (Communist controlled), pink (leaning Communist) or green (safe – for now). Only the United States and Ireland were green.

headline: Rose Evansky, a Pioneer in Women’s Hairstyling, Dies at 94
text: Rose Evansky, a British hairdresser who liberated women from the prison of the head-encasing domed dryer when she invented blow-dry styling at her London salon in the early 1960s, died on Nov. 21. She was 94.

headline: A Dangerous Choice for Ambassador to Israel
text: In appointing David Friedman as the next ambassador to Israel, Donald Trump voiced a desire to “strive for peace in the Middle East.” Unfortunately, his chosen representative would be far more likely to provoke conflict in Israel and the occupied territories, heighten regional tensions and undermine American leadership.

headline: Hotter Than Jalapeños
text: SATURDAY PUZZLE — Fashions come and fashions go, and the same could be said for trends in crosswords. Almost every day, words and phrases appear in crosswords for the first time and others return after a long absence. I can only speak to The New York Times Crosswords, but I love to see how language and usage evolves over time based on those trends. Thanks to websites like XWord Info, we can track those trends.

headline: The City Could Have Saved This 6-Year-Old
text: Zymere Perkins should be a happy, healthy little boy today. He should be in school.

headline: Loretta Lynch’s Parting Message
text: During her final days as attorney general, Loretta Lynch is not uttering President-elect Donald Trump’s name at formal events. But the fear his election has sparked among marginalized communities was clearly on her mind this week as she delivered parting thoughts on civil rights.

headline: Art in a Time of Atrocity
text: This is the ninth in a series of dialogues with philosophers and critical theorists on the question of violence. This conversation is with Bracha L. Ettinger, a visual artist, philosopher and psychoanalyst.  Her most recent publication is “And My Heart Wound-Space,” published on the occasion of the 14th Istanbul Biennial.

headline: Now, America, You Know How Chileans Felt
text: DURHAM, N.C. — It is familiar, the outrage and alarm that many Americans are feeling at reports that Russia, according to a secret intelligence assessment, interfered in the United States election to help Donald J. Trump become president.

headline: U.S. Destroys 14 Tanks at ISIS-Held Base in Syria
text: WASHINGTON — American-led airstrikes have destroyed 14 Syrian Army tanks at a military base in central Syria that, just days earlier, had been captured by Islamic State fighters, the United States military said Friday.

headline: In India, a Clash at the Top of the Tata Empire Gets Ugly
text: MUMBAI, India — In India, where corruption is a fact of life, the Tata Group — a powerhouse conglomerate that makes Land Rovers, operates the historic Pierre Hotel in New York and sells the world Tetley tea — has been held up as the exception to the rule.

headline: What’s on TV Saturday: ‘The OA’ and ‘Midnight Special’
text: Mystery abounds as Netflix offers up a story of a miracle in “The OA,” and a couple of outlaws abduct a child wanted by religious extremists in “Midnight Special.” And Casey Affleck takes the “Saturday Night Live” stage.

headline: Not Even a Prosperous Slovakia Is Immune to Doubts About the E.U.
text: GABCIKOVO, Slovakia — Since Slovakia joined the European Union in 2004, Emil Hirjak’s fortunes have risen along with his country’s.

headline: Agony in a Venezuelan Mental Health Hospital
text: Inside a mental hospital in Venezuela, shortages of food and medicine torment psychiatric patients.

headline: ‘Get Out of Your Gilded Offices and Fight for Change’
text: Here are the top 10 comments of the week on our digital platforms, as selected by our readers and the journalists who moderate nearly every comment.

headline: Free Cash in Finland. Must Be Jobless.
text: OULU, Finland — No one would confuse this frigid corner of northern Finland with Silicon Valley. Notched in low pine forests just 100 miles below the Arctic Circle, Oulu seems more likely to achieve dominance at herding reindeer than at nurturing technology start-ups.

headline: A Founder of Odwalla Tries to Recapture His Mojo
text: LOS ANGELES — For the past 20 years, Greg Steltenpohl, an avant-garde jazz saxophonist turned beverage entrepreneur, has worked to rekindle the magic behind his greatest hit — and make peace with a nightmare that led to an abrupt fall.

headline: Temescal, Oakland: Multicultural and Gentrifying
text: An appealing neighborhood in North Oakland, Temescal has been developing with the unevenness of a colt, a resident said.

headline: Temescal, Oakland: Multicultural and Rapidly Gentrifying
text: Krista Knudsen Thomas has lived in Temescal, a vibrant multicultural neighborhood in North Oakland, Calif., since 2007. She moved into a 1920s house on 44th Street, one of a pair that the family of her then-boyfriend (now husband) had bought for a total of about $625,000. Her sister-in-law lives in the other house. “A little compound,” Ms. Knudsen Thomas, 41, calls the arrangement.

headline: No One Tells Megyn Kelly What to Wear
text: Megyn Kelly — breakout star of the 2016 presidential campaign, anchor of the “The Kelly File” on Fox News, current object of employment desire for multiple networks, best-selling author, mother, wife, daughter and friend (the last four being how she describes herself) — has something she wants everyone to know. Really. A lot. Listen up.

headline: We Were There: Reports From Our Far-Flung Correspondents in 2016
text: The New York Times put journalists on the ground in more than 150 countries over the last year, covering nearly every corner of the world. Here are some of the most gripping tales from our foreign correspondents, photographers and editors in 2016.

headline: Kelly Oxford Is Looking for Peace of Mind
text: On a bleak-for-Los Angeles morning this month, Kelly Oxford — author, mother, social media activist and provocateur — sat in a coffee shop where she had never been before, tapping away texts to her mom and friends, and talking about her late dog Lou, a toy poodle who was made so popular by her Instagram feed that he has attracted his own press attention. Lou’s death has disrupted not only Ms. Oxford’s life, but also her daily routine.

headline: In Winter, Hotel Bargains in Northern Climes
text: With the snowbird migration underway, warm-weather deals can be hard to find. But winter is a good time to seek a bargain in cities, especially cities where the cold weather may be bleak. But what’s a little rain to a museum-goer?

headline: Bombing in Turkey Kills 13 Soldiers and Wounds Dozens More
text: A car bombing in central Turkey killed 13 soldiers and wounded more than 50 other members of the military on Saturday, the latest in a series of attacks in the country.

headline: A Little Variety
text: VARIETY PUZZLES — This week’s puzzles include:

headline: How a Putin Fan Overseas Pushed Pro-Trump Propaganda to Americans
text: The Patriot News Agency website popped up in July, soon after it became clear that Donald J. Trump would win the Republican presidential nomination, bearing a logo of a red, white and blue eagle and the motto “Built by patriots, for patriots.”

headline: Wonder and Worry, as a Syrian Child Transforms
text: TORONTO — As soon as Bayan Mohammad, a 10-year-old Syrian refugee, arrived here last winter, she began her transformation. In her first hour of ice-skating, she managed to glide on her own. She made fast friends with girls different from any she had ever known. New to competitive sports, she propelled herself down the school track so fast that she was soon collecting ribbons.

headline: Farhad’s and Daisuke’s Week in Tech: Is Google’s Waymo Way Better?
text: Each Saturday, Farhad Manjoo and Mike Isaac, technology reporters at The New York Times, review the week’s news, offering analysis and maybe a joke or two about the most important developments in the tech industry. Mike is away this week, so Daisuke Wakabayashi, a Times technology reporter, took pity on Farhad and chatted with him.

headline: Harassing the Super
text: Q. I am on the board of a small co-op in Midtown Manhattan. For the past year, a shareholder has had frequent and noisy sexual encounters in his apartment, making it difficult for the superintendent, who lives in the apartment below, to sleep. After the super complained to the shareholder and to the board, the shareholder began harassing her. He would ring her bell as he entered the building, sometimes at 3 or 4 in the morning, awakening her before his noisy assignations began. Because the shareholder is a lawyer, the board members are afraid that if we confront him he will retaliate against the board and individual members. How can we stop his uncivil behavior?

headline: What Do Trump Voters Want?
text: Brad DeLong has an interesting meditation on markets and political demands — inspired by a note from Noah Smith — that offers food for thought. I wonder, however, if Brad’s discussion is too abstract; and I also wonder whether it fully recognizes the disconnect between what Trump voters think they want and reality. So, an entry of my own.

headline: China Agrees to Return Seized Drone, Ending Standoff, Pentagon Says
text: BEIJING — The Pentagon on Saturday said that Beijing had agreed to return an underwater drone seized by China in international waters, an indication that the two countries were moving to resolve an unusual incident that risked sharpening tensions in the run-up to the inauguration of President-elect Donald J. Trump.

headline: Trading the ‘Ugliness’ of Drugs and Jail for Motherhood and College
text: Beverly Emers strode through campus with assurance, her 13-year-old son, Jabari, a few paces behind, as she gave the history of each monument at Bronx Community College this fall. Although decades older than most students there, Ms. Emers, 43, cannot walk between the buildings without someone waving, calling her name or inviting her to a party.

headline: Lara Rubinstein and Jeremy Clyman: In a World of Angry Couples, a Happy One
text: Lara Beth Rubinstein, the daughter of Barbara Kluger and Bruce Rubinstein of Old Bridge, N.J., was married Dec. 17 to Jeremy Andrew Clyman, a son of Judy Clyman and Robert Clyman of North Caldwell, N.J. Rabbi Lawrence Malinger, a friend of the bride’s family, officiated at the Cranwell Resort in Lenox, Mass.

headline: Variety: Marching Bands
text: VARIETY PUZZLES — Marching Bands is one of my favorite Variety puzzles. I know this sort of enthusiasm should have worn off by now, but I’m still amazed when the Rows and the Bands work out.

headline: Fordham Basketball Coach Recruits With an Academic Fast Track
text: When Coach Stephanie Gaitley is out recruiting for her Fordham women’s basketball team and sitting in the living rooms of potential players and their parents, she gives an unconventional spiel.

headline: Outsiders Selected by Trump Aim to Unnerve Washington
text: They are President-elect Donald J. Trump’s disrupters.

headline: Gunmen in Afghanistan Kill 5 Female Airport Employees
text: KANDAHAR, Afghanistan — Gunmen in the southern Afghan city of Kandahar opened fire on a van carrying female airport employees on Saturday morning, killing five women and their male driver, officials said.

headline: Minnesota Players Rescind Boycott and Will Play in Holiday Bowl
text: The University of Minnesota football team on Saturday rescinded its threatened boycott of a bowl game, a protest that had been intended to persuade the administration to lift the suspensions of 10 players entangled in a sexual assault inquiry. Team leaders continued to say that the 10 players, whose suspensions remain in effect, were being punished without the benefit of due process.

headline: Miami Beach Tries to Tame Its Most Raucous Street (but the Fishbowl Drinks Can Stay)
text: MIAMI BEACH, Fla. — From rooftop bars and rope lines to gridlocked streets and sidewalks, Ocean Drive, the once-idyllic neon heartbeat of South Beach, can trample the senses on most weekends.

headline: Donald Trump’s Foreign Policy Team: Built to Fail
text: WASHINGTON — With the announcement that he will nominate the Exxon Mobil chief executive Rex Tillerson as his secretary of state, President-elect Donald J. Trump has rounded out a foreign policy team that is, to put it mildly, profoundly different from that of any of his six Republican predecessors since World War II. It’s also unlikely to last particularly long.

headline: In Turkey’s Home of St. Nick, Far From North Pole, All Is Not Jolly
text: DEMRE, Turkey — The jagged Taurus Mountains rise on one side of the church, while the Mediterranean Sea gleams in the distance on the other. The bougainvillea is in bloom, the orange trees bursting with ripe fruit. It is, in other words, a long way from here to the North Pole.

headline: As President Joseph Kabila Digs In, Tensions Rise in Congo
text: KINSHASA, Democratic Republic of Congo — In a mansion along the Congo River, with a collection of expensive watches, expensive motorcycles and a chimpanzee in a cage, Joseph Kabila, the president of this vast and troubled country, should be packing up.

headline: Tim Raines’s Hall of Fame Candidacy in Last of the 10th
text: A defining measure of Tim Raines’s greatness probably never appeared on his baseball cards. Year after year, for the Montreal Expos and beyond, Raines would reach base around 40 percent of the time. Yet even Raines could not have told you his on-base percentage.

headline: Aleppo Rebuilt, With Cardboard and Colored Pencil
text: Mohammed Qutaish, who was born in Aleppo, was 10 when popular protests broke out against President, Bashar al-Assad of Syria. “I wasn’t sure exactly what was going on but I liked it. It felt positive,” Mohammed told me during one of our video-chats earlier this year. However, protesters were met with force, violence escalated and soon Mohammed and his family fled their beloved city. When they returned four months later, having been told that it was safely under the control of opposition forces, they were shocked to see the city in ruins.

headline: E.U. Faces Its Next Big Test as France’s Election Looms
text: LE LUC, France — When the French put a draft Constitution for a newly enlarged European Union to a referendum in 2005, Pascal Verrelle voted passionately against it — hoping it would stop the European Union in its tracks. He rejoiced when the effort failed, yet was dismayed when the bloc kept gathering more members and powers, anyway.

headline: Afghanistan to Investigate Vice President on Charges of Assaulting a Rival
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — The office of Afghanistan’s attorney general said on Saturday that it had opened an investigation into allegations that the country’s vice president had tortured and sexually abused a political rival.

headline: Donald Trump on Campus
text: After the election: What happens when conservative students want safe spaces, too.

headline: A Pro Bono Dream Team Takes On the N.R.A.
text: A promising new force in the fight for gun control has arrived on the scene. A coalition that includes corporate litigators from seven of the nation’s leading law firms is taking aim at some of the most glaring flaws in gun safety. One is Congress’s restriction of the government’s ability to conduct basic public health research on gun deaths. The lawyers will also seek ways to challenge state lawmakers who have invited millions of citizens to pack guns in public buildings and businesses.

headline: The Strip
text: A weekly comic strip featured in the Sunday Review.

headline: Donald Trump: The Russian Poodle
text: In 1972, President Richard Nixon’s White House dispatched burglars to bug Democratic Party offices. That Watergate burglary and related “dirty tricks,” such as releasing mice at a Democratic press conference and paying a woman to strip naked and shout her love for a Democratic candidate, nauseated Americans — and impelled some of us kids at the time to pursue journalism.

headline: Preaching the Gospel of Diversity, but Not Following It
text: ONLY two of the 20-plus reporters who covered the presidential campaign for The New York Times were black. None were Latino or Asian. That’s less diversity than you’ll find in Donald Trump’s cabinet thus far. Of The Times’s newly named White House team, all six are white, as is most everyone in the Washington bureau.

headline: Will Donald Trump Cave on Social Security?
text: Donald Trump campaigned on a promise not to cut Social Security, which puts him at odds with the Republican Party’s historical antipathy to the program and the aims of today’s Republican leadership. So it should come as no surprise that congressional Republicans are already testing Mr. Trump’s hands-off pledge.

headline: ‘I Wish I Had a Pair of Scissors, So I Could Cut Out Your Tongue’
text: One evening after school, about three weeks ago, my husband and daughter were on the curb in the too-early dark with the usual group of kids and parents, when my 5-year-old informed another mom that an older boy had come up to her son on the bus and said, “I wish I had a pair of scissors, so I could cut out your tongue.”

headline: Behold, Steve Bannon’s Hip-Hop Shakespeare Rewrite: ‘Coriolanus’
text: PORTLAND, Ore. — Soon after Stephen K. Bannon was appointed chief strategist for President-elect Donald J. Trump, profiles noted that he was a co-author of a rap musical based on Shakespeare’s Roman tragedy “Coriolanus.” The revelation played as a punch line, another loopy swerve in a career that took Mr. Bannon from a working-class Democratic family to the Trump White House. Coming just after Mr. Trump denounced the hip-hop hit “Hamilton” as “overrated,” the news that his right-hand man had scripted a hip-hop statesman himself felt almost comical.

headline: White Resentment on the Night Shift at Walmart
text: Seven years ago, I joined the night shift at a Walmart in rural Michigan. For $8.10 an hour, I spent four or five nights a week filling shelves with the flour and sugar and marshmallow fluff that residents of the local county, which in 2008 voted for Barack Obama, needed to get through the holidays. Four years ago, the county went with President Obama a second time, though by a thinner margin. But this past November, the county, like the state, turned red.

headline: One Way Not to Be Like Trump
text: THE Trump era will be unpredictable in many ways. But there’s one thing that we can reasonably count on. Moderation, an ancient virtue, will be viewed with contempt. After all, the most temperamentally immoderate major party nominee in American history ran for president and won because of it. Victory spawns imitation, and the Trump template is likely to influence our politics for some time to come.

headline: What Donald Trump Doesn’t Know About Black People
text: In 2005, after Hurricane Katrina, Kanye West appeared on live TV during a celebrity fund-raiser for victims of the disaster and said, “George Bush doesn’t care about black people.” This wasn’t based on intimate knowledge of Mr. Bush’s racial views, but rather on his treatment of black people in a time of crisis.

headline: My Family Was Interned. Now They’re With Trump.
text: When I was growing up my family simply called it “camp,” like the summer retreat I would escape to as a kid. Both places tended to have wood cabins, tight rows of beds and a large mess hall. My grandmother, or Baachan as I called her, used to say the baseball diamonds at her camp would draw huge crowds for every game.

headline: Unequal Sentences for Blacks and Whites
text: Decades of research have shown that the criminal courts sentence black defendants more harshly than whites. But a striking new investigation of sentencing disparities in Florida by The Sarasota Herald-Tribune expands our understanding of this problem in two important ways.

headline: Arguing the Truth with Trump and Putin
text: We are once again engaged in an argument about facts. Such arguments can feel deceptively substantive. This one certainly does.

headline: The Tent Cities of San Francisco
text: SAN FRANCISCO — California may be the new capital of American liberalism, but everybody who likes the sound of that ought to consider the fate of three recent San Francisco ballot initiatives.

headline: From Afar, an Extra Set of Eyes to Spot Concussions in the N.H.L.
text: With his team tied with the Minnesota Wild at 1-1 in the second period on Dec. 4, Edmonton Oilers Coach Todd McLellan received an unexpected visit from the referee T. J. Luxmore that left him shaking his head.

headline: Dr. Henry J. Heimlich, Famous for Antichoking Technique, Dies at 96
text: It is called the Heimlich maneuver — saving a choking victim with a bear hug and abdominal thrusts to eject a throat obstruction — and since its inception in 1974 it has become a national safety icon, taught in schools, portrayed in movies, displayed on restaurant posters and endorsed by medical authorities.

headline: Obama Confronts Complexity of Using a Mighty Cyberarsenal Against Russia
text: WASHINGTON — Over the past four months, American intelligence agencies and aides to President Obama assembled a menu of options to respond to Russia’s hacking during the election, ranging from the obvious — exposing President Vladimir V. Putin’s financial ties to oligarchs — to the innovative, including manipulating the computer code that Russia uses in designing its cyberweapons.

headline: Israel, a Medical Marijuana Pioneer, Is Eager to Capitalize
text: JERUSALEM — Israeli scientists began their pioneering research to isolate the psychoactive ingredient in marijuana with a 10-pound stash seized by the Tel Aviv police. That effort, in the 1960s, helped propel Israel to the vanguard of research into the plant’s medicinal properties and lay the foundations for a medical marijuana industry.

headline: Five Years Without a Pro Title? Oh, Woe Is the New York Sports Fan
text: The Knicks are finally respectable again, the Giants seem headed toward a playoff berth, and the Rangers own one of the better records in their conference. The Mets recently re-signed Yoenis Cespedes, and the Yanks threw a Boss’s ransom, old style, at Aroldis Chapman.

headline: Letters to the Editor
text: To the Sports Editor:

headline: Grambling Holds Off North Carolina Central on Blocked Kick
text: Grambling State won the Celebration Bowl when it blocked a late extra-point kick, which had been set back 15 yards by an excessive-celebration penalty, to hold off North Carolina Central, 10-9, in Atlanta on Saturday.

headline: In Mick Mulvaney, Trump Finds Anti-Establishment Leader for Budget Office
text: WASHINGTON — When the government was hours away from shutting down in 2011, Representative Mick Mulvaney gathered with his three fellow South Carolina Republican freshmen in a Capitol Hill chapel to seek spiritual guidance on how to vote on a measure to keep the lights on. The verdict: Vote “no.”

headline: Trump’s Win Helps Carve a Path to Washington for the ‘Cajun John Wayne’
text: CROWLEY, La. — In mid-December last year, Capt. Clay Higgins of the St. Landry Parish Sheriff’s Office was standing before a camera for a Crime Stoppers video, lecturing three at-large suspects in the thefts of several four-wheelers.

headline: Mirror Reflections
text: SUNDAY PUZZLE — UPDATE regarding the Mega Puzzle in the Sunday, December 18, 2016 Puzzle Mania print insert: There are two 387D numbers in the grid. The second is supposed to be 388D, and does not affect the solving of the puzzle.

headline: Trump Ends ‘Thank You’ Tour on Familiar Theme: Reveling in His Victory
text: MOBILE, Ala. — It was here, some 16 months ago, that Donald J. Trump displayed the sheer power behind his candidacy, packing this aging gridiron with tens of thousands of fans braving traffic and the August sun to get a glimpse of a candidate who, despite his swelling crowds and soaring poll numbers, was still being dismissed as a long shot.

headline: Quotation of the Day
text: “What they gave us, a brother wouldn’t even give to his own brother.”

headline: Corrections: December 18, 2016
text: BOOK REVIEW

headline: Benjamin Gilman, a New York Congressman for 30 Years, Dies at 94
text: Benjamin A. Gilman, a New York congressman for 30 years and a leading Republican critic of the Clinton administration’s foreign policy initiatives, died on Saturday in Wappingers Falls, N.Y. He was 94.

headline: Searcy Milam, Brooks Morgan
text: Searcy LaMarr Milam and Brooks Andrew Morgan were married Dec. 16 at Prospect House, an event space in Dripping Springs, Tex. The Rev. David DeSalvo, an Episcopal priest, officiated.

headline: Susie Campbell, Brian Harbour
text: Susie Elizabeth Campbell, the daughter of Janet E. Campbell and Michael S. Campbell of Swampscott, Mass., was married Dec. 16 to Brian James Harbour, a son of Lori A. Harbour and Ronald E. Harbour of Birmingham, Mich. The Rev. Noel Clarke, a minister affiliated with CITI Ministries, officiated at the Loeb Boathouse in Central Park.

headline: Sara Lewin, Zachary Lebwohl
text: Sara Beth Lewin, the daughter of Jeanette D. Lewin of Woodland, Calif., and Harris A. Lewin of Davis, Calif., is to be married Dec. 18 to Zachary Lebwohl, a son of Vida Lebwohl and Dr. Oscar Lebwohl of Scarsdale, N.Y. Rabbi Jonathan Seth Morgenstern is to officiate at the Hilton Westchester in Rye Brook, N.Y.

headline: Caroline Reid, Robert Jones II
text: Caroline Shackelford Reid, a daughter of Claire S. Reid and George C. Reid of Atlanta, was married Dec. 17 to Robert Arthur Jones II, a son of Robert A. Jones and Melinda W. Jones of Charlotte, N.C. The Rev. Robert Dunham, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony at the University Presbyterian Church in Chapel Hill, N.C.

headline: Jayne Blandford, Alexander Hubbard
text: Evelyn Jayne Blandford and Alexander Isaac Hubbard are to be married Dec. 18 at the Housing Works Bookstore Cafe in New York. Mark Giller, a Sanctuary of the Beloved minister, is to officiate.

headline: Antonia Rahneva, Matthew Karlan
text: Antonia Antonova Rahneva, the daughter of Anton V. Rahnev of Chandler, Ariz., and the late Vania G. Rahneva, was married Dec. 17 to Matthew Moler Karlan, a son of Carey M. Karlan of Darien, Conn., and Mitchell A. Karlan of Old Greenwich, Conn. P. Kevin Castel, a judge of the United States District Court for the Southern District of New York, for whom the groom was a law clerk, officiated at the Lafayette Grand Café and Bakery in New York.

headline: Genevieve Haverstick, James Fraser
text: Genevieve Munroe Haverstick, a daughter of Jessica Whalen Haverstick and S. Alexander Haverstick II of Short Hills, N.J., was married Dec. 17 to James William Fraser, a son of Valerie Jean Fraser of Tewksbury, N.J., and the late R. Bruce Fraser. The Rev. Jacob A. Smith, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at the Chapel of St. George’s Church in New York.

headline: Kate Ottaviano, Dustin Brockner
text: Kate Elizabeth Ottaviano, the daughter of Catherine A. Ottaviano and David A. Ottaviano of Dubai, United Arab Emirates, was married Dec. 17 to Dustin Jacobs Brockner, a son of Audrey J. Brockner and Joel Brockner of New Rochelle, N.Y. Dr. Todd M. Poret, a cousin of the groom who became a minister of American Marriage Ministries for the occasion, officiated at Maritime Parc, an event space in Jersey City.

headline: Kerry Billings, Thomas Shelford
text: Kerry Marie Billings and Thomas Joseph Shelford were married Dec. 17 at the Norwood Club, a private club in New York. Michael F. Mullen, a friend of the groom’s parents and a retired justice of State Supreme Court in Riverhead, N.Y., officiated.

headline: Madeleine Pilchak, Alexander McMall
text: Madeleine Mae Pilchak, a daughter of Therese M. Pilchak and Dr. Gary W. Pilchak of Brighton, Mich., was married Dec. 17 to Alexander Michael McMall, the son of Elizabeth M. McMall and Gary A. McMall of Saginaw, Mich. The Rev. Pat O'Connor, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at the Cathedral of the Most Blessed Sacrament in Detroit.

headline: Victoria Ervin, Derek Aguirre
text: Victoria Jean Ervin and Derek Daniel Aguirre were married Dec. 17 by the Rev. Maryjane Peck, an Episcopal priest, at Christ Church in Detroit.

headline: Bridget Dries, Bryan Georgiana
text: Bridget Catherine Dries, the daughter of Nancy M. Dries and Robert C. Dries Sr. of Millburn, N.J., was married Dec. 17 to Bryan Jeffrey Georgiana, a son of Karen E. Gecht and Jeffrey F. Georgiana. The Rev. Christopher Beirne, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at the Chapel of the Immaculate Conception at Seton Hall University in South Orange, N.J.

headline: Even With Diminished Hopes, Fans Find Jets Wanting Against Dolphins
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — Steve Bosque and his three buddies had just finished their first shot of Fireball whiskey in Section G7 of a half-empty Jets parking lot on Saturday night when the conversation turned especially bleak.

headline: What’s on TV Sunday: ‘The Sound of Music’ and ‘The Hollow Crown’
text: Dig out your toy microphone as the “The Sound of Music” makes its annual holiday appearance. Benedict Cumberbatch and Tom Sturridge continue their portrayal of Shakespeare’s kings in “The Hollow Crown.” And “The Traffickers” wraps up its season.

headline: ‘S.N.L.’ Hammers Donald Trump as a ‘Gift’ to Vladimir Putin for Christmas
text: Though there is still a week until Christmas, “Saturday Night Live” has already seized the opportunity to leave a lump of coal in the stocking of President-elect Donald J. Trump.

headline: Lascaux Caves, Paleolithic and New Again
text: More than 50 years after the Lascaux caves were closed to the public, a new exhibition, featuring a reproduction of the prehistoric cave art, has opened.

headline: Trump’s Electoral College Victory Ranks 46th in 58 Elections
text: President Trump claimed he won the electoral vote in a “landslide,” but he ranks below most presidents in the electoral vote and popular vote margins.

headline: The Electoral College Meets Monday. Here’s What to Expect.
text: Follow the latest updates on Monday’s vote on our Electoral College Briefing.

headline: Aleppo, Vladimir Putin, Donald Trump: Your Weekend Briefing
text: Here are the week’s top stories, and a look ahead.

headline: Polar Bears’ Path to Decline Runs Through Alaskan Village
text: KAKTOVIK, Alaska — Come fall, polar bears are everywhere around this Arctic village, dozing on sand spits, roughhousing in the shallows, padding down the beach with cubs in tow and attracting hundreds of tourists who travel long distances to see them.

headline: Seeking a Fountain of Youth for Old Masters
text: LENS, France — Trying to make the old look young is one of the abiding fixations of our times. Not only have human beings become disinclined to age gracefully — 60 has become the new 50 (or is it 40?) — but our material culture is continually being given a face-lift to remain relevant.

headline: Muted U.S. Response to China’s Seizure of Drone Worries Asian Allies
text: BEIJING — Only a day before a small Chinese boat sidled up to a United States Navy research vessel in waters off the Philippines and audaciously seized an underwater drone from American sailors, the commander of United States military operations in the region told an audience in Australia that America had a winning military formula.

headline: Bipartisan Letter Seeks Single Inquiry Into Russian Hacking Claims
text: ■ Four senators, including Republicans John McCain and Lindsey Graham, called for a select committee to investigate Russian hacking of the American election process.

headline: Insurance Policies on Slaves: New York Life’s Complicated Past
text: New York Life, the nation’s third-largest life insurance company, opened in Manhattan’s financial district in the spring of 1845. The firm possessed a prime address — 58 Wall Street — and a board of trustees populated by some of the city’s wealthiest merchants, bankers and railroad magnates.

headline: Egyptian Novelist Jailed on Obscenity Charges to Be Released
text: CAIRO — Egypt’s highest appeals court on Sunday suspended the prison sentence of Ahmed Naji, a prominent writer who had been convicted on charges of obscenity, in a decision that paved the way for his release, his lawyer said.

headline: In a Year of Crime News, Some Dark Deeds Yield Dead Ends
text: “I just called the police,” the angry man on the other side of the apartment door said after I knocked and introduced myself. “They’re on the way.”

headline: Cancer Patient Awaits Day She Can Return to the Kitchen
text: Stuffed inside cookie tins and between the pages of books in Diane Fields’s kitchen are multitudes of recipes. Ms. Fields has clipped them from newspapers and kept them for years, intent on preparing and sampling them all.

headline: Gunmen in Jordan Kill 10, Including 7 Officers and a Canadian Tourist
text: AMMAN, Jordan — Seven Jordanian security officers, a Canadian tourist and two Jordanian civilians were killed by gunmen in the southern city of Karak on Sunday, according to a joint statement from the Public Security Department and the Jordanian armed forces.

headline: What to Cook This Week
text: Good morning. This is going to be a weird week whatever you do for a living, however you worship or don’t, wherever you stand on the political spectrum, all across the United States. There are coming holiday feasts. But before those, everything is errands and secrecy, everyone is squirreling away gifts for loved ones, and many are packing their suitcases for long travel and forced cheer.

headline: ISIS Suicide Attack Kills 48 in Southern Yemen
text: AL MUKALLA, Yemen — A suicide bomber disguised as a disabled man blew himself up at a gathering of Yemeni security officers in the southern port of Aden on Sunday, killing 48 people and wounding dozens of others, Yemeni officials said.

headline: Le Train Bleu Is Departing Bloomingdale’s. A Rail Buff Sees It Off.
text: The train expert from the New-York Historical Society took a seat in a restaurant that looks like a dining car on a train. It only looks like a dining car. There is no engine at one end and no caboose with an observation platform at the other, but like so many trains — the Twentieth Century Limited, the Rip Van Winkle, the Phoebe Snow or the Southerner, to name only four — this one is approaching the end of the line.

headline: Aleppo Evacuations Will Be Monitored After U.N. Reaches Deal
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — The removal of residents from besieged communities in Syria bogged down again on Sunday after rebels opposed to the agreement set fire to buses that were supposed to carry evacuees, while Security Council diplomats signaled that they had reached a compromise deal to send United Nations monitors to oversee the evacuations.

headline: N.F.L. Playoffs: Cowboys, Patriots and Raiders Hold Tight to Top Spots
text: The N.F.L. playoff picture became much clearer on Sunday, with the Patriots, Raiders and Cowboys all tightening their grips on the top spots. Elsewhere, the Packers threw a wrench in the Lions’ plans in the N.F.C. North, and the A.F.C. South is still a mess. Here’s what we learned in N.F.L. Week 15:

headline: A Vestige of the Original World Trade Center Returns to Duty
text: On Monday, thousands of subway riders getting off trains at Chambers Street in Lower Manhattan will pull open metal-and-glass doors that have been closed for years and stream through a travertine-paved passageway.

headline: Russia Set to Block U.N. From Monitoring Aleppo Evacuation
text: UNITED NATIONS — Russia said on Sunday morning that it would block an effort to deploy United Nations observers in Syria to witness the evacuation of thousands of men, women and children from eastern Aleppo, or what the United Nations chief, Ban Ki-moon, has described as “a synonym for hell.”

headline: No Surprise: ‘Rogue One’ Triumphs at Box Office
text: LOS ANGELES — The offscreen stakes were minimal: “Rogue One,” the first in a series of “Star Wars” spinoff films planned by Walt Disney Studios, was always going to be devoured by moviegoers worldwide. No test of galactic franchise sustainability here.

headline: Longtime Business Lobbyist Laments Loss of ‘Smoke-Filled Rooms’ in Washington
text: R. Bruce Josten has been in the middle of the biggest deals in Washington over the past few decades without ever holding office, working on Capitol Hill or serving in the White House.

headline: Will Fiscal Policy Really Be Expansionary?
text: It’s now generally accepted that Trumpism will finally involve the kind of fiscal stimulus progressive economists have been pleading for ever since the financial crisis. After all, Republicans are deeply worried about budget deficits when a Democrat is in the White House, but suddenly become fiscal doves when in control. And there really is no question that the deficit will go up.

headline: Aleppo, China, Jordan: Your Morning Briefing
text: Good morning.

headline: Police and Civilians Killed in Jordan
text: Several Jordanian security personnel and civilians, including a Canadian tourist, were shot and killed on Sunday by gunmen in the southern city of Karak.

headline: Israel Reaches Agreement to Relocate Amona Settlers
text: AMONA OUTPOST, West Bank — With just days to go before a looming deadline for a court-ordered dismantling of this illegal Israeli settler outpost, Amona’s residents agreed on Sunday to a government proposal to relocate many of their homes to an adjacent plot of land on the same West Bank hilltop — a solution critics have denounced as just as illegal.

headline: Turkey and Iran’s Dangerous Collision Course
text: Today’s competition between Turkey and Iran is the latest iteration of an old power game: a struggle their progenitors, the Byzantine and Persian empires, started over the control of Mesopotamia — today’s Iraq and Syria. While the rivalry outlived their transformation from empires to nation-states, they have managed to keep the peace between themselves for nearly 200 years.

headline: Arsenal Can’t Avoid Collapse, or Paying Its Stars
text: MANCHESTER, England — It is late in coming, but it has at last arrived.

headline: Hong Kong’s Leader, Loyal to a Fault
text: Hong Kong — In the quiet of a recent Friday afternoon, Hong Kong’s hard-line leader, Leung Chun-ying, announced in a subdued, sometimes hesitant, voice that he would not seek a second term as chief executive. He cited the need for more time with his family: One of Mr. Leung’s daughters has long been afflicted with mental-health issues.

headline: Heng on Australia’s Refugee Policy
text: Australia has lowered global standards on how to deal with refugees, shifting the boundaries of what nations now find acceptable.

headline: Indonesia’s Dire Need for Engineers Is Going Unmet
text: JAKARTA, Indonesia — Like many college students, Abdul Hamid is not thinking too much about life after graduation.

headline: Al Pacino and Judith Light to Star in Play About Tennessee Williams
text: Al Pacino and Judith Light — two award-winning stalwarts of the stage and screen — will star as Tennessee Williams and his close friend in Dotson Rader’s “God Looked Away” at the Pasadena Playhouse in California, ahead of a possible Broadway run.

headline: Beckham’s Score Helps Giants Beat Lions in a Showdown of Top Teams
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — So often already in his young N.F.L. career, Odell Beckham Jr. has seemed to lift the Giants to victory with his exceptional receiving gifts.

headline: Commerce Dept. to Revise Growth Figures; Nike and FedEx to Announce Earnings
text: Here’s a look at what’s coming up this week.

headline: Patti Smith, in Surprise Appearance at MoMA, Says What’s on Her Mind
text: A week before Christmas, in the midst of a Midtown Manhattan decked in its holiday finery, Patti Smith, New York City’s punk poet laureate, gave an unannounced performance before a fast-gathering crowd of several hundred in the lobby of the Museum of Modern Art.

headline: The Mosque Next Door: City Law vs. Houses of Faith
text: BERNARDS TOWNSHIP, N.J. — Mohammad Ali Chaudry, a retired financial officer, has lived in this prosperous town for 40 years. It is where he raised his three children and where he served as mayor, and before that, as a member of the school board. It was also where Mr. Chaudry, an observant Muslim, always wanted to pray.

headline: As Prices for Classical Scores Soar, One Beethoven Is in Question
text: When a 232-page handwritten score of Mahler’s epic Second Symphony (“Resurrection”) sold for $5.6 million at Sotheby’s in London last month, it shattered a nearly 30-year record for the highest price paid at auction for a musical manuscript.

headline: Review: ‘Debriefing the President’ Tears Into the C.I.A.
text: Most C.I.A. memoirs are terrible — defensive, jingoistic and worst of all, tedious. Others are doomed by the C.I.A.’s heavy-handed and mandatory censorship.

headline: Review: Paul Taylor’s ‘Tracer’ Recalls a Dance and an Artist
text: The choreographer Paul Taylor, who is preparing his next premiere for March, has been making dances since 1954. But there’s one curious divide within his output, too little discussed. Between 1954 and 1962, he made a series of 17 works with designs by the artist Robert Rauschenberg; the last of these was “Tracer.”

headline: Inside the Ku Klux Klan, With an A&E Documentary Series
text: The setup is warm and fuzzy. “Girls, I got y’all some gifts,” says Steven Howard, presenting his two young daughters with prettily wrapped packages, which they eagerly rip into. The cameras then reveal what’s inside: the distinctive pointed hoods of the Ku Klux Klan.

headline: Review: ‘Mytho? Lure of Wildness’ Teases the Senses
text: Pale flesh is the first thing we see, examined at very near range by the eye of a video camera. In the opening moments of Anna Kohler’s “Mytho? Lure of Wildness,” it roves over breasts and belly as a fingertip touches this body, which is neither firm nor svelte.

headline: New Game Shows for a Fractious Age
text: If you watch game shows just to test your wits, congratulations on your kind heart; on Jan. 1, ABC rolls out a second season of its revamped version of “To Tell the Truth” just for you. If, on the other hand, you watch game shows in the hope of seeing relationships destroyed, heart attacks induced and humanity’s less-appealing instincts courted, three new shows might hit your sweet spot.

headline: All This Talk of Voter Fraud? Across U.S., Officials Found Next to None
text: [Read more about fake ballots, mail-in voting and voter fraud.]

headline: Santa Player
text: MONDAY PUZZLE — The winter holidays are a week away and, like Santa’s arrival at the end of the Macy’s Thanksgiving Day Parade, we welcome his arrival to The New York Times Crossword.

headline: Forget ‘Pat the Bunny.’ My Child Is Reading Hemingway.
text: Alice Hemmer’s favorite part of Jack Kerouac’s novel “On the Road” doesn’t involve the drug-addled cross-country road trips, encounters with prostitutes in Mexico or wild parties in Manhattan. Alice, who is 5 and lives in a Chicago suburb, likes the part when Sal Paradise eats ice cream and apple pie whenever he feels hungry.

headline: When Donald Trump Partied With Richard Nixon
text: HOUSTON — They still talk about the Saturday night here 27 years ago when Donald J. Trump partied with former President Richard M. Nixon.

headline: Selling Jewelry With a Crowdfunding App and Dash of Social Sharing
text: What happens when you throw together an entrepreneurial supermodel, a charitable crowdfunding app, lots of glittery gems and the odd paper-flower crown? David Yurman is hoping that the answer will be holiday brand-building magic.

headline: Zsa Zsa Gabor’s Lavish Life
text: The Hungarian actress Zsa Zsa Gabor played the femme fatale in dozens of film and television roles.

headline: Zsa Zsa Gabor, Actress Famous for Her Glamour (and Her Marriages), Dies at 99
text: Zsa Zsa Gabor, the Hungarian actress whose self-parodying glamour and revolving-door marriages to millionaires put a luster of American celebrity on a long but only modestly successful career in movies and television, died on Sunday in Los Angeles. She was 99.

headline: A Jewish Player’s 1914 Baseball Card Triggers a $125,000 Dispute
text: More than a hundred years after Guy Zinn last appeared in a major-league game, his baseball card is causing a commotion.

headline: Zsa Zsa Gabor’s Life
text: The Hungarian actress Zsa Zsa Gabor played the femme fatale in dozens of film and television roles.

headline: With Comic Book, Celebrities Pay Tribute to Orlando Victims
text: The comic book author and screenwriter Marc Andreyko felt unfathomable horror when he heard the news of the June 12 mass shooting at the Pulse nightclub in Orlando, Fla. Feeling compelled to help, he posted on Facebook a suggestion to create a comic book that would benefit the victims.

headline: Hungry, Thirsty and Bloodied in Battle to Retake Mosul From ISIS
text: ISTANBUL — After two months, the battle to retake the Iraqi city of Mosul from the Islamic State has settled into a grinding war of attrition. The front lines have barely budged in weeks. Casualties of Iraqi security forces are so high that American commanders heading the United States-led air campaign worry that they are unsustainable. Civilians are being killed or injured by Islamic State snipers and growing numbers of suicide bombers.

headline: In Sag Harbor, a Beloved Cultural Oasis Is Lost
text: The program scheduled at the Sag Harbor Cinema over the weekend was typically offbeat: It included a French film about a philosophy professor facing a midlife crisis and a documentary about a Dutch immigrant who turned an old plow horse into a show jumping champion.

headline: By Attacking the Press, Donald Trump May Be Doing It a Favor
text: The answer to all the troubling new questions about the future of the news business — how to make money, stop the spread of fake news and reassert a uniform view of reality — appeared last week in a plate of “flaccid, gray Szechuan dumplings.”

headline: 57 Years Later, Even the Library Had Stopped Counting the Fines
text: In her 20th-floor apartment on the East Side of Manhattan, on a recent Saturday afternoon, Barbara Roston was busy explaining that she was definitely not a thief.

headline: Snapchat Plays Hard to Get With Celebrities and Influencers
text: SAN FRANCISCO — The musician Jay Sean has visited the headquarters of YouTube, Facebook and Twitter. Instagram has reached out to tutor him on the best time to post photos for maximum impact.

headline: Margot Wallstrom on Feminism, Trump and Sweden’s Future
text: UNITED NATIONS — Margot Wallstrom, Sweden’s top diplomat, has sought to advance what she calls a feminist foreign policy. What does that mean?

headline: Proud to Be a Sanctuary City
text: If the next president’s immigration agenda includes a pitched battle over “sanctuary” cities, a term Donald Trump uses with disgust, the proper response from places like New York will be: Bring it on.

headline: A World of Surveillance Doesn’t Always Help to Catch a Thief
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Earlier this year, I had a beer in one of the more budget-conscious bars in the Mission district. My wallet stayed a little later than I did.

headline: 来自阿勒颇的绝望信息
text: 激烈的战斗之后，叙利亚政府军重新占领了阿勒颇东部大部分区域。在仅剩的反对派控制的区域里，民众和活动人士通过视频描述了他们内心的恐惧。

headline: A (Short) Lifetime Spent Preparing for the Family Business
text: With a baby face that belies even his tender age, Alexandre Tanguay is still occasionally stopped by security personnel in opposing arenas and asked to present his bona fides.

headline: Clashes in Chechen Capital Leave at Least Seven Militants Dead
text: MOSCOW — At least seven militants were killed and three hospitalized with gunshot wounds after two clashes with special forces rocked the mountain republic of Chechnya over the weekend.

headline: Roger Federer Welcomes the End ... Of a Layoff, Not His Career
text: The Federer family has shared many a road trip, but in this unusually settled period, the patriarch and primary breadwinner has been fielding more and more questions.

headline: Quotation of the Day
text: “They don’t look like polar bears. But it does not matter. I will Photoshop them when I get home.”

headline: The N.B.A.’s Back-to-Back Problem: ‘Rest? It’s Your Job, Man!’
text: Lee Winfield’s teammates can still remember him coming to their homes in his Volkswagen van. It was the signal of the start of another trip for the Buffalo Braves in the early 1970s, back when N.B.A. players flew with the general public, washed their own uniforms and endured bone-crushing schedules.

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for the Week of Dec. 19
text: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes Monday’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

headline: Senators Push to Broaden Inquiry on Election Hacking
text: WASHINGTON — Pressure mounted on Sunday for a broader congressional investigation of Russian cyberattacks aimed at influencing the American election, even as a top aide to President-elect Donald J. Trump said there was no conclusive evidence of foreign interference.

headline: Monday’s N.F.L. Matchup: Carolina Panthers (5-8) at Washington Redskins (7-5-1)
text: 8:30 p.m. Eastern, ESPN Line: Redskins by 6 ½

headline: So Order the Tongue
text: Dear Diary:

headline: William Hudnut, Mayor Who Transformed Indianapolis, Is Dead at 84
text: William H. Hudnut III, who in his four terms as mayor of Indianapolis revitalized the city’s downtown with a focus on professional sports, died on Sunday in Chevy Chase, Md. He was 84.

headline: Cardinal Paulo Evaristo Arns Dies at 95; Fought Torture in Brazil
text: Cardinal Paulo Evaristo Arns, whose advocacy of human rights in Brazil placed him in opposition to a military dictatorship that engaged in systemic torture, died on Wednesday in São Paulo. He was 95.

headline: Review: The Songs of Noël Coward, With Lightness and Bite
text: No matter how festive your holiday party season may be, it is unlikely to reach the heights, or depths, described in Noël Coward’s irresistibly funny song “I Went to a Marvelous Party,” a highlight of “Life Is for Living,” a tribute to Coward created and performed by Simon Green and his accompanist at the piano, David Shrubsole.

headline: A Sneak Peek at the 2nd Avenue Subway
text: As the city’s newest train line nears completion, we take you into the stations along the route that will house the artwork of Chuck Close, Sarah Sze, Vik Muniz and Jean Shin.

headline: ‘The Affair,’ Season 3, Episode 5: Back to Block Island
text: Like salmon heading upriver to spawn, Noah and Alison got back on the boat to Block Island on Sunday’s night’s episode of “The Affair.” They had sailed this route before — in Season 1, Episode 4 — with momentous results: the consummation of their affair and the first complete account of the death of Alison’s son, the Eros and Thanatos from which everything in the show has flowed.

headline: Devils Lose More Ground With Shootout Loss to Rangers
text: Two hours before he played his third road game in four days, Devils center Travis Zajac strode to the work bench outside the team’s dressing room at Madison Square Garden on Sunday and tinkered with his stick, lightly tapping it on the floor to make sure it felt just right.

headline: Aleppo, China, Zsa Zsa Gabor: Your Monday Briefing
text: Good morning.

headline: Sylvester Stallone Suggests He Would Decline Trump Arts Role
text: Sylvester Stallone suggested on Sunday that he was not interested in taking a top arts leadership role in the Trump administration, including as chairman of the National Endowment for the Arts.

headline: What’s on TV Monday: Michelle Obama on ‘An Oprah Winfrey Special’
text: Michelle Obama speaks with Oprah Winfrey about her legacy as first lady. HBO explores the risks of too much holiday imbibing. And LeBron James oversees a different kind of ballgame in “The Wall.”

headline: Word + Quiz: funereal
text: : suited to or suggestive of a grave or burial

headline: Kering’s Latest Luxury: A Generous Parental Leave Policy
text: Kering, the French luxury-good group that owns the brands Alexander McQueen, Saint Laurent and Gucci, among others, and has made something of a mission out of championing women’s rights — with initiatives like the Chime for Change campaign for female empowerment, the “Women in Motion” talks for film industry professionals and a partnership with the United Nations Women French National Committee — has put its human-resources policy where its cause is.

headline: Russian Military Plane Carrying 39 Crashes in Siberia
text: A Russian military plane crashed early Monday in eastern Siberia, according to the official Tass news agency, which said 16 of the 39 people on board were seriously injured.

headline: Eight Creative People Recommend Their Favorite Classic Books
text: Despite the influx of new things to read this holiday season, there’s nothing quite like curling up with a classic. Every week, creative people share the 10 titles they would most want with them if they were marooned on a desert island — a part of the editor Aaron Hicklin’s ongoing project OneGrandBooks.com. Here, eight recommend the classics that have stuck with them.

headline: Deadly Remnants of Asbestos in Italy
text: Asbestos was banned by the end of the 20th century, but people exposed to it in the 1970s and 1980s continue to be cut down by cancer and other illnesses related to the once-common material.

headline: What Are Your Thoughts on Riding the School Bus?
text: Do you ride a school bus? If not now, did you ever ride the bus to and from school? What is behavior like on your bus? What, if anything, would you change about the experience of riding the bus?

headline: Indefinite
text: In Britain, some immigrants face a future of indefinite detention.

text: To the Editor:

headline: On College Campuses, Does ‘Liberal’ Mean ‘Illiberal’?
