headline: Planned Hong Kong Museum Will Showcase China’s Imperial Relics
text: BEIJING — In a sign of growing cultural ties between mainland China and Hong Kong, officials in Hong Kong have announced plans to build a museum to serve as a permanent display space for objects from Beijing’s Palace Museum, home to some of China’s most treasured imperial artifacts.

headline: Dying in Police Custody in India
text: Nearly 600 people died in police custody in India between 2010 and 2015, yet not one police official was convicted during this period. A report released by Human Rights Watch last week examines 17 cases in which families have sought accountability. Their stories reveal, in searing detail, why there have been so many deaths, starting with police contempt for proper procedures, a cavalier attitude toward the torture of detainees and near total impunity for wrongful deaths.

headline: For Russians, Bleak Realities at Home
text: MOSCOW — Russian hackers have been making front pages recently in the United States and Europe, but few people in Russia seem to care or even notice. The Russia of international media and the Russia that we, Russians, know from the inside could not be further apart.

headline: China’s Cybersecurity Efforts Could Pose New Challenge for Foreign Firms
text: HONG KONG — It has been a tough year in China for America’s technology companies.

headline: Without Obama, Shinzo Abe’s Approach to U.S.-Japan Ties May Be Tested
text: TOKYO — Since becoming prime minister for the second time in 2012, Shinzo Abe has made it a centerpiece of his foreign policy to steer Japan closer to the United States.

headline: California Today: And the Californian of the Year Is …
text: Good morning.

headline: Favorites From Douthat, Kristof and Rosenthal
text: We continue today with more Times columnists selecting a favorite column from 2016 and saying a few words about it. Along with those words, I’ve listed the column written by each that attracted the largest online audience among Times subscribers.

headline: As Hopes for European Unity Dim, New E.U. Headquarters Are Glowing
text: BRUSSELS — A giant glowing orb is about to become the new home of the European Union.

headline: A New Champagne for the New Year
text: In making Champagne, the dominant grapes are chardonnay and pinot noir, but the unsung hero is pinot meunier, often contributing fruit and freshness to the wine. Arlaux is one of the few wineries that depend on the grape, which accounts for about a third of the plantings in the Champagne region. A family-run estate on property farmed since the 12th century, Arlaux has made Champagne since 1826 but only now is exporting to the United States. The house makes eight Champagnes, all premier cru, notably the Brut Grande Cuvée, which is lovely, straightforward and yeasty, with lively acidity: Arlaux Brut Grande Cuvée nonvintage, $43 for 750 milliliters, Vintry Fine Wines, 230 Murray Street (West Street), 888-686-8767, vintryfinewines.com.

headline: Denver’s Gritty Back Door Could Become Its New Gateway
text: DENVER — A checkerboard of low-slung buildings and vacant parcels, the River North Art District in this fast-growing city has developed a funky vibe over the last few years.

headline: Midwest Cheeses With a French Pedigree
text: Among the cheeses made by Jacobs & Brichford is a stunner, Briana with truffles. It’s semisoft, almost lacy, and has an alluringly funky edge. The farm in Connersville, Ind., specializes in French cattle breeds whose milk results in cheeses like the prizewinning Everton Premium Reserve, spicy and fairly sharp, with a craggy texture. Other varieties ripen to satin creaminess, like the fruity Ameribella and the mushroomy JQ: Jacobs & Brichford Farmstead Cheeses, $5.75 to $6.75 per quarter pound, jandbcheese.com.

headline: Entertaining Shortcut From a Jar
text: Store shelves are lined with sauces and spreads galore, and newcomers show up all the time. This unusual aioli and a dusky blend of mushrooms and black truffles from a new company, Delicious & Sons, get a thumbs up. Use the orange-scented aioli straight from the jar with seafood or a paella. Toss pappardelle in the mushroom-truffle mix, thinned with a little pasta water: Delicious & Sons, 6.35-ounce jars, deliciousandsons.com, garlic aioli with saffron and orange, $8.95; black truffle and mushroom sauce, $12.35, amazon.com.

headline: Good, Bad and Mad: Andrew Rosenthal on the News of the Year
text: Times Insider delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how news, features and opinion come together at The New York Times. In this podcast, Andrew Rosenthal, a Times Op-Ed columnist, talks about the news of 2016 — the good, the bad and that which makes him mad.

headline: The Calzone’s Cousin Comes to Greenwich Village
text: “New York has every kind of food, but no place that sells panzerotti,” said Christian Francone, who has filled the gap with a sliver of a shop selling the Southern Italian turnovers. “They’re very popular in Italy.” His family is originally from Barletta, in Apulia, home of the fried half-moon snack his shop offers. Twelve fillings are available, including three sweet choices; the savory options, especially those with tomato and mozzarella with or without sausage or pepperoni, taste something like fried pizza. Smoked chicken with pesto and mozzarella, and spinach with ricotta offer a nice change of pace. For now he makes only 100 per day and closes the shop once they are sold. But soon he expects to stay open as late as 3 a.m. on weekends: Mr. Panzerotto, 124 Macdougal Street (Minetta Lane), 646-964-5035, mrpanzerotto.com.

headline: Splatter Away With These Pollock Place Mats
text: Messy eaters? Not a problem when the table is set with these vinyl place mats in a dense Jackson Pollock pattern from the Museum of Modern Art. No drip will show. The only question is, what took the museum so long to come up with the idea? There is also a handsome table runner, 14 by 60 inches, with swaths of white, gray and black on a taupe ground. They’re based on Pollock’s “Number 1A, 1948” and “Number 7, 1950”: Jackson Pollock place mats, $24, table runner $65, momastore.org.

headline: Giving Up ‘Mostly Everything’ to Care for His Wife
text: “Don’t scratch it.”

headline: Tariffs and the Trade Balance (Wonkish) (Updated)
text: Before the election, I wrote that I intended to spend the time after in an orgy of serious policy analysis – because I thought we were going to have a president serious about policy. Sad! And in some ways it’s hard to stay motivated about economic analysis when we’re in fact going to have a government that is completely uninterested in analysis, evidence, or truth of any kind.

headline: 1891: Two Englishmen Found Guilty on Charges of Espionage
text: SAINT ETIENNE — John Samuel Cooper and Walter Bednell, the alleged English spies, were brought up for trial before the St. Etienne police magistrates yesterday. The court was crowded, the case having touched a very sensible chord of the French national character.

headline: Trump Picks Thomas Bossert as Top Counterterrorism Adviser
text: WEST PALM BEACH, Fla. — President-elect Donald J. Trump has named Thomas P. Bossert, a top national security aide under President George W. Bush, to be his homeland security adviser, the Trump transition team announced Tuesday morning.

headline: Chocolate Made With Olive Oil
text: The chef and restaurateur Thomas Keller is now in the chocolate business: a bean-to-bar partnership with Armando Manni, a Tuscan olive oil producer. The idea was born five years ago, when the men were discussing the antioxidant properties of dark chocolate and olive oil. The results, called K & M Extravirgin Chocolate (they say it “K plus M”), are made in a former warehouse in Napa, Calif., where the cacao undergoes a special, gentler process to preserve the bean’s antioxidant properties. Mr. Manni’s olive oil is used in place of cocoa butter. The 75 percent cacao bars come in three varieties, according to the source of the chocolate. The Peruvian bar has coffeelike depth, the bar from Ecuador is smooth with woodsy hints of chestnut, and the Madagascar bar is spicy with notes of pineapple and passion fruit. You do not taste the olive oil: K & M Extravirgin Chocolate, $14.95 for 2.5 ounces at Williams-Sonoma stores, williams-sonoma.com, $120 for eight bars from kellermannichocolate.com.

headline: Mindy Kaling, Sterling K. Brown, Thomas Middleditch and Bob Odenkirk on Their Favorite TV of 2016
text: We asked some of this year’s notable authors, actors and showrunners about the TV they enjoyed most in 2016. Their responses will run over the next two weeks. Come back to Watching, The New York Times’s TV and movie recommendation site, to read them all.

headline: Shining Light on a Windows 10 Search
text: Q. The search box in Windows XP was friendly and found things. The search function on Windows 10 is basically useless because it rarely finds anything I seek, including documents I worked on the day before. Is there a way to get reliable search results using Windows 10?

headline: Marriage May Help You Survive a Stroke
text: Your marriage status may be a good predictor of whether you survive a stroke.

headline: Trump Inauguration Security Planners Brace for Wave of Protesters
text: WASHINGTON — Security surrounding the inauguration of Donald J. Trump is proving to be the most challenging in recent history, according to senior officials involved in its planning, largely because of the same forces of political rancor that shaped the race for the presidency.

headline: Daily Report: Inside Snopes, a Fighter of Fake News
text: Since the presidential election, fake news has been in the spotlight for how its spread online may have influenced the American electorate. So what is it like to be one of the fighters of this scourge?

headline: How Cuomo’s Signature Economic Growth Project Fell Apart in Utica
text: In Utica, a former industrial hub in upstate New York where the near collapse of manufacturing has made for a scarcity of jobs and a rarity of good news, the announcement in August 2015 that an Austrian chip maker had decided to put down roots in a fabrication plant built by the state was cause for jubilation.

headline: Pentatonix Climbs to No. 1 and George Michael’s Streams Soar
text: In the music charts this week, Pentatonix reaches No. 1 with its latest holiday album, and streams of George Michael’s music grew by nearly 3,200 percent after news of his death emerged on Christmas Day.

headline: As U.K. Tightens Voting Rules, Critics Say Labour and the Poor Will Suffer
text: LONDON — The British government announced plans on Tuesday to crack down on voter fraud by requiring voters to show official identification at polling stations, tightening rules on absentee ballots and preventing political activists from handling absentee ballots.

headline: Buffalo Bills Fire Coach Rex Ryan, Slamming Door on a Boisterous Presence
text: Rex Ryan needed just one more win — against the faltering Jets, no less — to become the first Buffalo Bills head coach in 16 years to post back-to-back .500 seasons.

headline: Clean Tech Rises Again, Retooling Nature for Industrial Use
text: BERKELEY, Calif. — A decade ago, a group of biologists, venture capitalists and computer whizzes gathered under the name “clean tech.” They hoped to overturn polluting industries with microorganisms cheerily excreting industrial chemicals through the miracle of reprogramming nature’s genetic code.

headline: School Parade in Taiwan Featuring Swastikas and Nazis Unleashes Uproar
text: TAIPEI, Taiwan — A high school parade in Taiwan in which students dressed as Nazi soldiers and carried swastika banners has created a storm of criticism in one of Asia’s most open societies.

headline: Taiwan Student's Nazi Costumes Spark Outrage
text: A parade on Friday in which high school students dressed as Nazi soldiers and carried swastika banners in Taiwan was met with strong condemnation. The parade was part of Hsinchu Kuang-Fu High School's anniversary celebration.

headline: Carrie Fisher
text: Carrie Fisher, the actress, author and screenwriter, became a film star with the release of “Star Wars” in 1977.

headline: Carrie Fisher, Child of Hollywood and ‘Star Wars’ Royalty, Dies at 60
text: Carrie Fisher, the actress, author and screenwriter who brought a rare combination of nerve, grit and hopefulness to her most indelible role, as Princess Leia in the “Star Wars” movie franchise, died on Tuesday morning. She was 60.

headline: Workplace Deaths
text: To the Editor:

headline: China Deploys Aircraft Carrier to Disputed South China Sea
text: BEIJING — The Chinese military, in a move analysts described as a challenge to President-elect Donald J. Trump’s strident criticism of China, has deployed an aircraft carrier to patrol the contested South China Sea, officials said on Tuesday.

headline: Richard Adams, Whose Novel ‘Watership Down’ Became a Phenomenon, Dies at 96
text: Richard Adams, the British novelist who became one of the world’s best-selling authors with his first book, “Watership Down,” a tale of rabbits whose adventures in a pastoral realm of epic perils explored Homeric themes of exile, courage and survival, died on Saturday. He was 96.

headline: Best of The Times’s Live Interactive Journalism on Facebook Live in 2016
text: Since April, The New York Times has been creating a new type of content: live interactive journalism. While streaming on Facebook, our journalists have explored stories hand in hand with the viewer. Here are some of our audience favorites from the year: live concerts, live reporting, live drawing, and more. Please send us questions and comments here: LIJTeam@nytimes.com.

headline: United Nations, Donald Trump, Shinzo Abe: Your Morning Briefing
text: Good morning.

headline: Watch These Movies and TV Shows Before They Leave Netflix on Jan. 1
text: At the end of every month, movies and TV shows expire from various streaming services. Here are the most interesting titles leaving Netflix at the end of December.

headline: The U.N. Resolution Against Israeli Settlements
text: To the Editor:

headline: A Flock in Need
text: Cheesemakers love sheep’s milk, but the animals’ inability to produce the volume of milk needed for profitability is putting strains on some dairies.

headline: Sheep’s Milk Cheeses in U.S. Earn Ribbons but Little Profit
text: Seated with hundreds of colleagues at the American Cheese Society awards ceremony in Des Moines this past July, Rebecca Williams heard her farm’s name announced not once but twice, for its acclaimed sheep’s milk cheeses.

headline: Record Rainfall Closes Australian National Park
text: Meteorologists say this type of weather event only happens twice a century.

headline: After 15 Big Mall Fights, Police See a Culprit: Teenage Boredom
text: Officer Tamara Valle of the Fort Worth Police Department received a call on Monday: A fight had broken out in the food court of the nearby Hulen Mall, and 200 teenagers were running, screaming and fighting. Shopkeepers were going into lockdown, slamming their gates shut with customers still inside.

headline: Recent Commercial Real Estate Transactions
text: $2.3 MILLION

headline: ‘The Public Domain’: An Afternoon Too Hot to Sing. Or So I Thought.
text: When I first heard that David Lang was composing a piece for a thousand voices, professional and amateur, to be performed outdoors around the fountain in Lincoln Center Plaza, the idea seemed a little gimmicky. Still, I was curious about the piece, titled “the public domain.”

headline: How Donald J. Trump Could Promote Long-Term Economic Growth
text: Despite hand-wringing before the election that a Trump presidency would presage near-term and long-term calamity, giddy equity markets responded to a Republican sweep of the White House and Congress with a more sanguine view. Such a response makes sense if a pro-growth policy is indeed much more likely, but it also lays bare steps the new administration and its economic team need to take to justify that optimism.

headline: Death of a Red Carpet Reporter
text: Jeffrey Slonim didn’t shout. While the other red carpet reporters tried to get the attention of celebrities by yelling their names, he usually waited for them to come to him. And they usually did.

headline: Plundering the Classics for Children
text: To the Editor:

headline: The Start of a New Arms Race?
text: To the Editor:

headline: The Stone Announces Its End Date
text: The Stone, an influential East Village performance space owned by the composer-improviser John Zorn, appears to have announced its end date — in February of 2018. The club’s calendar for that month, which includes a “Farewell to the Stone” celebration, was singled out on Monday in the Twitter feed of Destination: Out, a two-person team of advocates of avant-garde jazz.

headline: Walmart Slowly Makes Strides in E-Commerce
text: Walmart Stores’ tortoise-like digital pace may yet pay off.

headline: The Odeon
text: A downtown landmark still hits the spot.

headline: The Odeon’s Not-So-Bright Lights Still Beckon
text: Why do I keep going back to the Odeon?

headline: Houses of Worship Poised to Serve as Trump-Era Immigrant Sanctuaries
text: PHILADELPHIA — Tucked one floor below the majestic Gothic sanctuary of Arch Street United Methodist Church, Javier Flores Garcia sleeps on a cot in a basement Sunday-school classroom that church members have outfitted with a microwave, a compact refrigerator and a television.

headline: Questions About George Michael’s Death Remain as His Inner Circle Mourns
text: The body of George Michael, the British pop star who died on Sunday at 53, was discovered on Christmas Day by his boyfriend, Fadi Fawaz, at the singer’s home in the village of Goring-on-Thames, according to an account published on Tuesday by The Daily Telegraph.

headline: Mehdi Karroubi, Iranian Cleric Under House Arrest, Quits Political Party
text: Mehdi Karroubi, an Iranian cleric who ran for president in 2009 in an election that was followed by protests and a brutal crackdown, has resigned from his political party, according to the Iranian news media.

headline: Dressing Up as Princess Leia: Share Your Photos
text: Did you or a family member ever dress up as Princess Leia? We’d like to see your photos and the story behind them.

headline: At Salons and Spas, Membership Plans Catch On
text: Every few weeks, on the way home from her downtown Manhattan office, Rebecca Weinreich stops in at a club in TriBeCa. The airy space is outfitted with comfortable velvet sofas and a large crystal chandelier. Upon arrival, members like Ms. Weinreich are offered a flute of chilled prosecco or a freshly prepared latte.

headline: Don’t Let Trump Speak for Workers
text: “I am your voice,” President-elect Donald J. Trump declared at the Republican National Convention. In another campaign speech, he told his supporters, “I alone can fix it.”

headline: Review: ‘Ocean Waves,’ a Tale of Young Love, Ghibli Style
text: Studio Ghibli is revered by animation lovers the world over. During the company’s 31-year existence, its output has been relatively small, because the artists who founded it — Hayao Miyazaki, director of films including “Spirited Away” and “The Wind Rises,” is the most famous — are never less than painstaking.

headline: In Bahrain, Arabs and Jews Gather (and Dance) at a Hanukkah Celebration
text: Orthodox Jews in black coats and skullcaps danced with Arabs in flowing robes and checkered kaffiyehs at a Hanukkah celebration over the weekend in Bahrain, a Muslim-majority monarchy whose king has sanctioned celebrations of the Jewish holiday.

headline: Whitney Houston, Cher, Tina Turner and Donna Summer: The Musicals
text: Fans of shimmery miniskirts, hands-in-the-air choruses and beefcake backup dancers are in for a treat, as theater producers are turning to some of pop music’s biggest divas for their latest musical projects (and potential cash cows). News this month of a coming Tina Turner bio-musical is making it clear that producers “Believe” demand for such shows is “Strong Enough.” (Couldn’t help it, Cher.)

headline: Russians No Longer Dispute Olympic Doping Operation
text: MOSCOW — Russia is for the first time conceding that its officials carried out one of the biggest conspiracies in sports history: a far-reaching doping operation that implicated scores of Russian athletes, tainting not just the 2014 Winter Olympics in Sochi but also the entire Olympic movement.

headline: Baci e Vendetta Brings Old-World Elegance to the East Village
text: Here’s a stunning bar and trattoria with Old World bronze-trimmed elegance that outclasses its East Village location. It’s the work of the Church Group, which creates themed bars, several in the same neighborhood. Nearby, the group’s Kingston Hall is Jamaican, Shoolbred’s is as Scottish as its hot toddies, and Ninth Ward, which is closed temporarily, showcases the food and drink of New Orleans. (The group has opened another Ninth Ward in London.) Nic Ratner and Robert Morgan, a former Hollywood agent, are the partners. At the new Italian venture, a menu of small plates like crostini, panini, burrata, a chicken parm sandwich and meatballs is expanded for weekend brunch with the addition of egg dishes, a burger and French toast. The drinks — wine based, not spirits — are Italian-accented, with cocktails including a Bellini and a creditable Bloody Mary made with sake: 131 Avenue A (St. Marks Place), 646-275-0461, bacievendetta.com.

headline: Review: A Guitarist Rejects Her. But She Knows How to Be Cruel.
text: Noche Flamenca, the beloved flamenco troupe, can eschew spectacle and concepts for a simple presentation, because it can rely on its dependably thrilling star, Soledad Barrio. In recent years, though, the group has grown a little more theatrically ambitious, and a new pattern has emerged: longer works that take a season or two to find their footing.

headline: Fans and Friends Pay Tribute to Carrie Fisher
text: Celebrities and fans paid tribute to the actress Carrie Fisher, who died on Tuesday at the age of 60. Her death came days after a heart attack on a flight from London to Los Angeles. She was known for playing Princess Leia in the "Star Wars" films.

headline: What We’re Reading
text: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What We’re Reading emails are sent twice a week. Sign up »

headline: Report on Bronx Teacher's Relationship With a Student
text: The details of Isaac Duran’s relationship with Felicia Barahona, when he was a student and she was a teacher, are recounted in a four-page memorandum written by the office of the special commissioner of investigation for the New York City School District.

headline: A ‘Nutcracker’ Dream: The Role of Dewdrop
text: #SpeakingInDance: a new weekly visual exploration of dance. Follow us on Instagram: @nytimes.

headline: Review: With ‘The Correspondence,’ a New Contender in the Ring
text: “Don’t make your books any shorter, please,” Graham Greene begged his friend Muriel Spark in a 1974 letter, “or you’ll disappear like Beckett.”

headline: Review: 1 Teenage Boy and 3 Mothers in ‘20th Century Women’
text: Love and loss go hand in hand in “20th Century Women,” a funny, emotionally piercing story about a teenager and the women who raise him. It opens in 1979, when cool kids danced to Talking Heads (“This ain’t no party, this ain’t no disco”) and President Carter bummed everyone out talking about our “crisis of confidence.” There’s something in the air — or so it seems, although the California light here tends to blot out the shadows. When a car bursts into flames soon after the movie opens, it looks about as threatening as an art installation. Apocalypse later, man.

headline: An Evening of Ronald K. Brown Lifts Alvin Ailey’s Season
text: There was one night (at least) this season — Dec. 14, to be exact — when everything came together for Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater. Movement melted off shoulders and fingertips without effort. Power emanated from the inside and then flowed out with searing swiftness, the rare sort that isn’t ostentatious. The men found strength in suppleness; the women were softer still, plush yet never weak.

headline: Grading the Big Deals of 2016: Low and Incomplete Marks Abound
text: It’s time to call an end to 2016 and hand out grades for good and bad deal-making. In a fitful and contentious year, it is perhaps no surprise that this year there were more bad grades than good.

headline: Carrie Fisher's 'Star Wars' Legacy
text: Manohla Dargis, a film critic for The New York Times, remembers Carrie Fisher, whose career was defined — for better or for worse — by her role as Princess Leia in the “Star Wars” films.

headline: Shinzo Abe at Pearl Harbor: ‘Rest in Peace, Precious Souls of the Fallen’
text: The following is a transcript of Prime Minister Shinzo Abe’s remarks on Tuesday at Pearl Harbor, Hawaii, based on an advance text of his speech.

headline: Japanese Leader Offers Condolences in Visit to Pearl Harbor
text: PEARL HARBOR, Hawaii — Seventy-five years after Imperial Japanese warplanes destroyed the Pacific fleet here and drew the United States into World War II, Prime Minister Shinzo Abe of Japan on Tuesday stood next to President Obama at the site of the attack and offered repentance but did not apologize.

headline: Review: In Jim Jarmusch’s ‘Paterson,’ a Meditative Flow of Words Into Poetry
text: Poems slip across the screen like water in “Paterson,” Jim Jarmusch’s wonderful new dispatch from Jarmusch-land. Sometimes they appear over water, too, surfacing word by word on images of the Great Falls along the Passaic River in Paterson, N.J. No pen or pencil directly spells out these words, no clattering keyboard or banging typewriter. Instead, the words — in a neat, cramped hand — appear onscreen as they are read aloud by their author, Paterson (Adam Driver), a soulful bus driver and basement poet. It’s as if he were beaming his heart-song straight from his head into yours.

headline: The Dark (and Often Dubious) Art of Forecasting Food Trends
text: Remember when wraps seemed revolutionary? Maybe you had one on your way home from an Alanis Morissette concert in 1996.

headline: Carl Paladino, a Trump Ally, Says Racist Remarks About Obamas Were Sent in Error
text: Carl Paladino said on Tuesday that he had not intended to send racist remarks about President and Michelle Obama, which were roundly denounced as viciously offensive, to a Buffalo newspaper for publication.

headline: National Biotechnology Panel Faces New Conflict of Interest Questions
text: The National Academies of Sciences, Engineering and Medicine are assigned by Congress to provide policy guidance to the government. The group describes itself as “advisers to the nation.” The advice often comes through written reports from scientific committees organized by the group.

headline: Bubble Tea? So 2002. A Sampling of Food-Trend Predictions
text: Some food-trend predictions flourish and some fizzle, but they offer a glimpse of how our cravings have (or haven’t) changed. Here is a sampling, from various sources.

headline: Shinzo Abe, Obama, Carrie Fisher: Your Tuesday Evening Briefing
text: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Bob Bradley Is Out at Swansea. Round Up the Usual Replacements.
text: There was a telltale line in the statement Huw Jenkins, the chairman of Swansea City, released Tuesday to confirm that Bob Bradley’s career as a Premier League manager was over after 85 days.

headline: Senators Reassure Wary Baltic Nations That U.S. Won’t Abandon NATO
text: LONDON — Three American senators arrived in Tallinn, Estonia on Tuesday to reassure the Baltic nations that the United States remained committed to their defense and to the NATO alliance.

headline: A New Day for Gay Plays?
text: No one would argue that gay men and women continue to face the kind of discrimination they did back in 1968, when Mart Crowley’s “The Boys in the Band” cracked open the closet door onstage, shining a stark light on what was then a topic rarely explored in popular culture.

headline: North Korea’s Nuclear Hopes Have Surged, Defector Says
text: SEOUL, South Korea — A senior North Korean official who defected to the South told reporters on Tuesday that the North viewed 2017 as the best time to advance its nuclear program because it could take advantage of leadership changes in the United States and South Korea.

headline: Carrie Fisher, a Princess, a Rebel and a Brave Comic Voice
text: Carrie Fisher was the child of a show-business family. “The daughter of famous parents,” she wrote in her memoir “Wishful Drinking,” which originated as a one-woman show. “One an icon, the other a consort to icons.”

headline: After Uncertain Year, New Administration Portends Shift in Wall Street Scrutiny
text: The Scottish poet Robert Burns once wrote “there is no such uncertainty as a sure thing.” There seemed to be any number of sure things this past year, from the outcome of the presidential election to how the Supreme Court would cut back on insider trading.

headline: Vera Rubin, 88, Dies; Opened Doors in Astronomy, and for Women
text: Vera Rubin, who transformed modern physics and astronomy with her observations showing that galaxies and stars are immersed in the gravitational grip of vast clouds of dark matter, died on Sunday in Princeton, N.J. She was 88.

headline: Art That’s Disposable, but by No Means Throwaway
text: Claude Monet found inspiration in haystacks and water lilies, Pablo Picasso in African masks and Edvard Munch in a poem he himself had written.

headline: A Song for Bill de Blasio Sounds a Sour Note for Watchdogs
text: Mayor Bill de Blasio posted a video on his City Hall Twitter account on Tuesday that featured two Broadway actors singing his praises and promoting his accomplishments, drawing criticism from government watchdog groups who said that it was an inappropriate use of public money and was too much like a campaign ad.

headline: 3 Men Made Millions by Hacking Merger Lawyers, U.S. Says
text: Law firms that advise on mergers once had to worry about a rogue employee trading on deal tips. Now, they have to worry about hackers doing the same.

headline: Carrie Fisher: A Look at Her Life Beyond ‘Star Wars’
text: Carrie Fisher was known worldwide for her portrayal of Princess Leia, the heroine and rebel leader at the heart of four “Star Wars” films, but she was quick to point out that she was much more than her creatively coifed character.

headline: Former Student Is Charged in Killings of Ex-Teacher and Their Son
text: It was a minor tabloid scandal: a Bronx high school teacher caught having a sexual relationship with a student. She was 32. He was in high school, 17 or 18. Soon, they moved in together and she was pregnant. They bought wedding bands.

headline: Romania’s President Rejects First Female Candidate for Prime Minister
text: BUCHAREST, Romania — President Klaus Iohannis of Romania on Tuesday rejected a candidate for prime minister put forward by the country’s largest political party, a decision likely to increase a rift between the president and the parliamentary majority.

headline: Rick Perry, as Energy Secretary, May Be Pressed to Resume Nuclear Tests
text: President-elect Donald J. Trump’s Twitter post last week that the United States must “greatly strengthen and expand its nuclear capability” provoked confusion and anxiety that intensified the next day when he added, in a television interview, “Let it be an arms race. We will outmatch them at every pass and outlast them all.”

headline: A Grand Central Dancer, Interrupted
text: Dear Diary:

headline: Alabama Win in 1926 Rose Bowl Put Southern Stamp on College Football
text: The first time Alabama played Washington, in the 1926 Rose Bowl, the Crimson Tide arrived in Pasadena, Calif., more than a week early. The Huskies, by contrast, did not come down from Seattle until the day before the game, because their officials had determined, according to a New York Times article from Dec. 26, 1925, that “experience has proved that the Huskies play better when they have not been exposed to the enervating Southern breezes for any length of time.”

headline: Gordie Tapp, ‘Hee Haw’ Regular of ‘Pfft! You Was Gone’ Fame, Dies at 94
text: Gordie Tapp, a regular for more than 20 years on the long-running television variety series “Hee Haw,” died on Dec. 18 in Burlington, Ontario. He was 94.

headline: Cristina Fernández de Kirchner Indicted Again on Corruption Charges
text: BUENOS AIRES — Cristina Fernández de Kirchner, the Argentine former president who with her late husband dominated the country’s politics for most of this century, was indicted Tuesday on fraud and corruption charges involving huge public works projects. It was her second indictment since she left office last year.

headline: John Kerry, in a Final, Pointed Plea, Will Outline a Vision of Mideast Peace
text: WASHINGTON — In a last-chance effort to shape the outlines of a Middle East peace deal, Secretary of State John Kerry plans to describe in a speech on Wednesday the Obama administration’s vision of a final Israeli-Palestinian accord based on bitter lessons learned from an effort that collapsed in 2014.

headline: Choir in Plane Crash Projects Russian Pride and Soft Power
text: Confusion has flooded the web since it was announced that dozens of members of the Alexandrov Ensemble, a famed army choir and orchestra, were among the 92 killed when a Russian military passenger plane headed for Syria crashed into the Black Sea on Sunday.

headline: Corrections: December 28, 2016
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: Trump Revives Defense of Charitable Foundation Amid Inquiry
text: Donald J. Trump has renewed his defense of his charitable foundation, insisting on Twitter that all of the money raised by the organization has gone to charity even as the New York attorney general continues to investigate claims to the contrary.

headline: Sell the Business, Not the Presidency, Mr. Trump
text: In recent days, the Trump family has announced some steps that it says are intended to address the truckload of conflicts of interest that Donald Trump could bring to the White House next month, and that it is considering further measures. But so far, these steps fall well short of what Mr. Trump must do to protect his presidency from damaging accusations of corruption.

headline: Quotation of the Day
text: “His approval rating is at 4 percent. So that gives Christie something to shoot for.”

headline: If You Build It, They Will Come
text: WEDNESDAY PUZZLE — Plenty of people play fantasy sports, but have you ever put together a fantasy musical group? With a group of people who are not musicians and whose raison d’être has nothing to do with music?

headline: Fans Tweet About Mental Illness to Honor Carrie Fisher
text: The actress Carrie Fisher, who spoke openly about her struggles with mental illness, once joked that she wanted to start a “Bipolar Pride Day” to help erase the stigma of the disease.

headline: Sluggish Rangers Rediscover Their Fight, Ending Senators’ Winning Streak
text: Ottawa Senators forward Chris Neil has amassed more than 2,500 penalty minutes in his 15-year N.H.L. career because he is not bashful about throwing around all of his 209 pounds. He did so again in the second period Tuesday, driving the rookie Rangers defenseman Brady Skjei into the boards and to the ice.

headline: H.I.V. Cases Surpass a Million in Russia, but Little Is Done
text: ST. PETERSBURG, Russia — Quietly, the number of Russians who have received a positive H.I.V. diagnosis passed the one million mark this year. There is, however, little indication that the government will commit adequate resources to stem the acceleration of the virus from high-risk groups into the general population.

headline: Carrie Fisher, Russia, Shinzo Abe: Your Wednesday Briefing
text: Good morning.

headline: Five Places to Shop in Copenhagen
text: The Vesterbro neighborhood of Copenhagen was once a seedy part of town that was full of brothels and was not to be ventured into at night. But in the last several years, it has become home to both fledgling and established entrepreneurs who are opening quirky boutiques with interesting back stories. Many of the locally owned shops are on or near a busy thoroughfare called Istedgade, and what they sell varies from children’s clothes to home goods.

headline: Phil Jackson of Knicks and Jeanie Buss of Lakers Announce Their Breakup
text: Phil Jackson and Jeanie Buss, one of the N.B.A.’s longest-running power couples, announced their breakup Tuesday night via social media.

headline: What’s on TV Wednesday: ‘Captain America’ and ‘Swan Lake’
text: “Captain America: Civil War,” a superhero film with relatively low stakes but suggestions of political commentary, is streaming on Netflix. And Rudolf Nureyev’s 1984 staging of “Swan Lake,” performed by the Paris Opera Ballet, is on medici.tv.

headline: For the Trumps, ‘Made in U.S.A.’ May Be a Tricky Label to Stitch
text: At Saks Off Fifth recently, an Ivanka Trump white polyester and spandex blouse made in Indonesia was marked down to $34.99, from $69. A few racks over, her black and white jacket came from Vietnam, while several blocks away, at Macy’s, her leather bootee manufactured in China sold for more than $100.

headline: Hospitals in Safety Net Brace for Health Care Law’s Repeal
text: PHILADELPHIA — Jason Colston Sr. went to the emergency room at Temple University Hospital last month with his calf swollen to twice its normal size. A bacterial infection had entered his bloodstream, requiring him to spend nine days at Temple, where patients are overwhelmingly poor.

headline: Photographing Climate Change Refugees, by Drone and on Foot
text: Josh Haner has photographed eight stories across five countries this year on the effects of climate change.

headline: Life on a Small California Farm
text: The work is grueling at Oya Organics, an 18-acre vegetable farm in Hollister.

headline: Europe Takes a Braver Stance on Gun Control
text: The European Union, to its credit, has agreed on a series of proposals for tighter gun controls as a timely response to the growing threat of terrorism and mass shootings. The proposals, which are headed toward a final vote by members next year, would extend bans on semiautomatic assault weapons to more models, institute medical checks for gun buyers, tighten sales on the internet and track the resale of guns to foil black-market dealers.

headline: Fix Immigration. It’s What Voters Want.
text: Donald J. Trump smashed many orthodoxies on his way to victory, but immigration was the defining issue separating him from his primary opponents and Hillary Clinton. President-elect Trump now has a clear mandate not only to stop illegal immigration, but also to finally cut the generation-long influx of low-skilled immigrants that undermines American workers.

headline: The Trump Matrix
text: Anyone who tells you, with perfect confidence, what a Trump administration will do is either bluffing or a fool. We have a prospective cabinet and a White House staff, but we haven’t got the first idea how the two will fit together or relate to Congress, or how the man at the top will preside over it all.

headline: Where Secret Arrests Were Standard Procedure
text: For a shocking glimpse of what’s been happening in the name of criminal justice in America, look no further than a Justice Department report last week on police behavior in Louisiana. Officers there have routinely arrested hundreds of citizens annually without probable cause, strip-searching them and denying them contact with their family and lawyers for days — all in an unconstitutional attempt to force cooperation with detectives who finally admitted they were operating on a mere “hunch” or “feeling.”

headline: How Donald Trump’s Health Secretary Pick Endangers Women
text: LOS ANGELES — With the selection of Representative Tom Price as secretary of health and human services, President-elect Donald J. Trump has taken a giant step toward undermining the health of American women.

headline: Chinese Prosecutors Ask Court for More Time in Detained Tibetan’s Case
text: The case of a Tibetan entrepreneur who was detained after being featured in an article and video by The New York Times has taken an unusual turn, with Chinese prosecutors asking a court for more time to investigate as the judges were weighing a trial.

headline: Photographing Climate Change Refugees, by Drone and on Foot
text: Josh Haner has photographed eight stories across five countries this year about the effects of climate change, often employing drones to get unique vantage points. Mr. Haner is a staff photographer and a senior editor for photo technology at The New York Times. He talked with James Estrin about finding new ways to visualize climate change. The conversation has been edited for clarity and brevity.

headline: And a Thinner New Year: Five New Books About Food and Diets
text: I’ve never understood why January is diet season. Don’t people realize they still have many months during which they can layer their layers? Every diet book should come out on May 1. That’s when you realize you have less than two months before someone, somewhere, is going to force you to go to the beach. But O.K., fine, “new year, new you” and all that. Let’s get a jump-start on the panic, shall we?

headline: Vivek Murthy Thinks We Need to Learn How to Deal With Stress
text: Why does the surgeon general wear a uniform? I wear the uniform of the U.S. Public Health Service Commissioned Corps, which evolved from a Marine hospital system headed by a supervising surgeon, later given the title of surgeon general. I like the uniform: There was a time when my friends wouldn’t let me leave the apartment without somebody first checking to make sure I wasn’t going to embarrass the group with what I was wearing, so having the uniform is helpful.

headline: Your Sister Won’t Vaccinate Her Son. Can You Help Him?
text: My sister and her ex are against vaccinating their kids, and I completely disagree with them. Vaccines have helped usher in the modern age; our life spans have been lengthened by the eradication or suppression of smallpox, polio, measles, flu, and so on. Recently, my 12-year-old nephew told me out of the blue that he wasn’t vaccinated and wanted to be. He got swine flu a year or two ago. He was very sick and has no desire to repeat anything like that again.

headline: The Fighter
text: Sam Siatta was deep in a tequila haze, so staggeringly drunk that he would later say he retained no memory of the crime he was beginning to commit.

headline: 11 Ways to Be a Better Person in 2017
text: Live like Bill, pay attention and learn how to iron a shirt.

headline: Berlin Attraction Reveals an Uneasy Phenomenon: Hitler Sells
text: What do you do about the buildings associated with Hitler’s life and death? In Austria, they are hitting the delete key, but in Germany, it’s more like copy and paste.

headline: How a Fish That Hatches in Coral Reefs Finds Its Way Home
text: The larvae of fish that live in coral reefs are tiny, and they are not very good swimmers. They are pushed by currents away from the reefs on which they were hatched for days or weeks until they learn to swim. Then, somehow, around 60 percent of them make their way back to their birthplaces, where they spend the rest of their lives.

headline: Manhattan Valley: A Diverse Neighborhood Bordering Central Park

headline: A Zika Vaccine, but for Whom?
text: The race for a Zika vaccine, one of the most pressing priorities in global health, is at full throttle. More than a dozen companies and government institutions are working to unlock the secrets of the virus, and a vaccine could be available as early as 2018.

text: Stuck at your work desk? Standing up and walking around for five minutes every hour during the workday could lift your mood, combat lethargy without reducing focus and attention, and even dull hunger pangs, according to an instructive new study.

headline: Faster Growth? Two Things Trump Supporters Won’t Like
text: Donald J. Trump wants us to dream bigger about the economic future. We shouldn’t be content with the roughly 2 percent annual growth that has been the norm this century, he has said. And he thinks he can bring about the kind of robust growth of 4 percent or more that was commonplace in decades past.

headline: ‘Why Are We Doing This to Ourselves?’ Readers Respond to the Threat of Automation
text: How do we deal with the job losses caused by automation? Offer a universal basic income? Halt the march of technology? Shorten the workweek? Get more education — or a different kind of it? Raise the minimum wage — or lower it?

headline: Tunisian Detained as Possible Accomplice in Berlin Attack

headline: London Nutcrackers Defy Logic, and Still Delight
text: LONDON — It hasn’t always been an inevitable truth here that “The Nutcracker” plays during the holiday season. But things seem to be changing, perhaps influenced by the belt-tightening in British arts funding and the moneymaking powers of this ballet: For the past few years, the English National Ballet and the Royal Ballet have both had long December-into-January runs of “The Nutcracker.”

headline: Near Mexico City, Cable Car Lets Commuters Glide Over Traffic

headline: Adam Driver Takes the Wheel
text: Typically during filming, Adam Driver explained, cast and crew members receive a sheet of short descriptions of the day’s scenes — snippets like “man argues with woman,” “man runs into road” and the perhaps inevitable “man gets hit by car.”

headline: Willa Kim, Designer of Fanciful Costumes, Dies at 99
text: Willa Kim, the petite and unfailingly elegant theatrical costume designer whose exuberant, sometimes over-the-top designs brought her two Tony Awards and a solid reputation for innovation in the dance world, died on Friday on Vashon Island, Wash. She was 99.

text: A Trump backer and a Clinton supporter sit down in Colorado to try to bridge the voter divide.

headline: Let’s Talk: A Clinton and Trump Supporter Together in Colorado
text: FRUITA, Colo. — There was no screaming or insults when Anne Keller and Jason Brown sat down at a coffee shop to talk politics from opposite sides of a table. They didn’t shout over each other like cable talking heads. They didn’t fire off nasty tweets. One liberal, one conservative, talking and listening to each other while a fresh glaze of snow melted outside.

headline: Trump Tower False Alarm Causes Real Evacuation, and Headache
text: Hundreds of suspicious packages in Midtown Manhattan were reported to the New York Police Department this year, but its response to one discovered at Trump Tower on Tuesday underscored the challenges and headaches that come with protecting the home of the president-elect.

headline: Homeland Security Bribe Documents
text: A review by The New York Times of thousands of court records and internal agency documents showed that over the last 10 years more than 200 employees of the Department of Homeland Security have taken nearly $15 million in bribes while being paid to protect the nation’s borders and enforce immigration laws. Here are some of cases we have highlighted from that investigation.

headline: The Enemy Within: Bribes Bore a Hole in the U.S. Border
text: WASHINGTON — In 2012, Joohoon David Lee, a federal Homeland Security agent in Los Angeles, was assigned to investigate the case of a Korean businessman accused of sex trafficking.

headline: Greed Springs Eternal
text: Jonathan Chait catches Larry Kudlow praising the Orange One for choosing a cabinet of billionaires, because rich men are incorruptible — after all, they don’t need even more money. As Chait says, this is ludicrous on its face; consider, for example, Russia’s oligarchs.

headline: 1966: U.S. Admits Bombing Damaged Civilian Areas in North Vietnam
text: WASHINGTON — The Pentagon has acknowledged that civilian areas in North Vietnam have been damaged during U.S. air raids, but declared that only military targets had been scheduled for attack.

headline: Text Messaging Takes More Apps Into a Chattier Realm
text: WHETHER it’s by iMessage, WhatsApp, Snapchat, or Facebook’s Messenger or Instagram, we collectively send billions of text messages daily. This fast-paced method of communication has become so ingrained that other apps have borrowed the chat format for different purposes.

headline: The xx Lets the Sunshine In
text: MARFA, Tex. — On a mid-October night, a few dozen people clustered near one end of the Lost Horse Saloon here: a small video crew, some Texas locals and tourists including visitors from New York City like me. Deer heads and skulls gazed down from the walls; a sign announced “Open Mic Night.”

headline: Chief of Dentsu, Japanese Ad Agency, to Resign Over Employee’s Suicide
text: TOKYO — In the months before she jumped to her death from a company dormitory last Christmas, a young employee at a Japanese advertising agency told friends on Twitter of enduring harassment and grueling long hours on the job.

headline: Shopping for Android Apps on the Web

text: WASHINGTON — Secretary of State John Kerry accused Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel on Wednesday of thwarting peace in the Middle East, speaking with a clarity and harshness almost never heard from American diplomats when discussing one of their closest and strongest allies.

text: One of the biggest crazes consuming Silicon Valley entrepreneurs and venture capitalists late in the last decade was “clean technology,” the kinds of technologies that would cut down on pollutants and dirty fuels.

headline: Berlin Cancels Rare Show of Modern Art from Tehran Museum
text: An exhibition in Berlin of artworks from the Tehran Museum of Contemporary Art was canceled after the museum authority in Berlin said Iran had not granted export permits for any of the works to be shipped to Germany. The Tehran Museum’s collection of Western modern art is widely considered to be the most important outside of North America and Europe, and this was the first time that a show of these works was to be staged outside of Iran.

text: “A kiss can be a blissful and heartfelt connector, a reminder about who and what matters most. A mindful kiss can make time stand still. Whether you’re with a long time partner or a new friend, allow yourself to be in it for all of the beauty and connection that a kiss holds.” — JoAnna Harper, Los Angeles-based Guiding Teacher, Against the Stream Buddhist Meditation Society.

headline: Review: In ‘Travelers,’ Some Serious Time-Sharing

headline: Suffolk County Opioid Deaths
text: Fentanyl, an anesthetic commonly used for surgery, has surpassed heroin to become the deadliest drug on Long Island. In Suffolk County, it has killed at least 126 people in 2016, according to records compiled by the medical examiner.

headline: Fentanyl Outpaces Heroin as the Deadliest Drug on Long Island
text: An anesthetic commonly used for surgery has surpassed heroin to become the deadliest drug on Long Island, killing at least 220 people there in 2016, according to medical examiners’ records.

headline: Nassau County Opioid Deaths
text: Fentanyl, an anesthetic commonly used for surgery, has surpassed heroin to become the deadliest drug on Long Island. In Nassau County, it killed at least 39 people in 2016, according to records compiled by the medical examiner.

headline: Record Overdoses Expected in New York City
text: In New York City, more than 1,000 people are expected to die from drug overdoses in 2016 — the first recorded four-digit death total in city history, according to statistics compiled by the Department of Health and Mental Hygiene. Nearly half of all unintentional drug overdose deaths in the city since July have involved fentanyl, the health department said.

Some are worn by familiar faces, like Anna Dello Russo and Giovanna Engelbert, but others are donned by relative unknowns, all hoping to grab the attention of the ever-present photographers and perhaps become a street style star.

headline: A Flashback to My Soviet Childhood
text: EAST WINDSOR, N.J. — The gas masks given to me and other Soviet first graders in 1987 were hand-me-downs from World War II, made of stiff rubber and too big for our faces. They trapped moisture and reduced the world to two blurry circles bouncing in front of my face. Our teacher didn’t tell us about the gas mask drill ahead of time — she simply handed out the masks, and we blindly paraded around the school before going back to our lessons. None of us bothered to ask why we were training. There was no need.

headline: Dutch Fertility Clinic Investigates Possible Sperm Mix-Up
text: AMSTERDAM — Twenty-six couples in the Netherlands are waiting to find out if the sperm that was used to fertilize their eggs at a reproductive technology clinic might have come from the wrong men.

headline: Israeli Mystery of Lost Babies Gets New Chapter: 200,000 Secret Records
text: JERUSALEM — Some Israeli families received army call-up papers and voter registration notices for children who had been declared dead as babies. Many others were never given an official cause of death by health officials, never saw the bodies of their infants and were never able to locate their graves.

text: These cool new products and collections will make sticking to your resolutions a little less daunting.

headline: A Men’s Wear Store Made for Men
text: The fact that men’s interest in fashion is now taken as a given, not a rare treat, cuts both ways. On the one hand, it is no longer easy to condescend to a consumer who has curiosity, access to information and capital. But a different sort of condescension has replaced the old one: selling mildly glamorous versions of the old unglamorous garments, and passing it off as an achievement all the way around.

headline: For Heart Health, the Most Dangerous Time of the Year
text: The rate of heart attack increases during the holiday season, but not just because of cold weather or the exertions of snow shoveling.

headline: Digitizing ‘Radio Unnameable,’ a Free-Form 1960s Crossroads
text: When the counterculture swept through America in the 1960s, few places were closer to the action than the studios of WBAI in Manhattan, where Bob Fass manned the microphone at midnight for his show, “Radio Unnameable.”

headline: ‘Language at the Speed of Sight’ Fights to Reopen Our Closed Book on Literacy
text: A few weeks ago, while we were all looking the other way, the triennial survey comparing the world’s educational systems came out. For America, the news wasn’t good. Math scores dropped, while reading numbers weren’t much different from last time. Neither finding puts us on course to lap Singapore anytime soon.

headline: In ‘Falsettos,’ an Affecting Echo of AIDS Anxiety
text: I felt like I had the wind knocked out of me, a sensation I had not experienced in decades — maybe even since I was a kid playing soccer (terribly).

headline: Last-Minute New Year’s Eve Looks
text: Need a last-minute New Year’s Eve look? Head to the Armarium pop-up at the Plaza Hotel before the clock strikes 12. There, fashion fairy godmothers (a.k.a. Armarium stylists) have entrance-making options like a Sonia Rykiel sequin dress ($500 rental, $4,050 retail) and a gold Roberto Cavalli gown ($1,000 rental, $11,000 retail) at the ready. At 768 Fifth Avenue

headline: In Hip-Hop, Inspiration Arrived by Way of Kirk Franklin
text: Kirk Franklin first came to crossover prominence in the mid-to-late 1990s as part of the first wave of gospel artists to take the sound and attitude of hip-hop seriously and incorporate them into their work. During that era, those worlds seemed to be miles apart. But time has a way of softening all barriers, and of late, the gospel impulse has firmly entrenched itself into hip-hop’s mainstream.

headline: Melina Matsoukas Touched Nerves From Behind the Camera
text: We take music videos for granted. In about 35 years, they’ve gone from an alleged scourge on the musical imagination to a form of oxygen. Every so often, one comes along that touches a nerve or causes a scandal. Back in February, on the eve of the Super Bowl, “Formation” stopped the nation. It was another Beyoncé sneak attack, but also a statement piece and a work of art. And for a month, the intent of its imagery — Beyoncé atop a sinking New Orleans Police Department cruiser; the witchiness of her wide-brimmed hat and her seemingly spiritually possessed head bob on the porch of a manse; a young black boy dancing before a phalanx of militarized cops — was deconstructed, debated and defended.

headline: Wadada Leo Smith, Raising Issues With a Horn
text: The trumpeter and composer Wadada Leo Smith made not one but two of this year’s standout jazz releases. “America’s National Parks,” a suite on two discs, features his Golden Quintet, made up of longtime associates like the pianist Anthony Davis and the drummer Pheeroan akLaff. “A Cosmic Rhythm With Each Stroke” is a duo session with another colleague, the pianist Vijay Iyer, inspired by the art of the Indian modernist Nasreen Mohamedi.

headline: How ‘Toni Erdmann’ Became an Unexpected Comedy
text: PARIS — The German director Maren Ade’s breakout film, “Toni Erdmann,” has won over audiences and racked up awards across Europe. An uncharacterizable father-daughter story that’s also about neoliberal economic reforms in Romania and the clash between the generation of 1968 and its capitalist children, the film is exceptional for another reason: It’s hilarious.

headline: Obama Designates Two New National Monuments, Protecting 1.65 Million Acres
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama designated two new national monuments on Wednesday, protecting 1.35 million acres of federal land surrounding the Bears Ears Buttes in southeastern Utah and about 300,000 acres around Gold Butte in Nevada, northeast of Las Vegas.

headline: On Small Screens at Year’s End: Weird Stuff Worth a Look
text: It’s the busy holiday season, so of course you haven’t had time to keep up with the weird, the obscure and the underappreciated in the small-screen-viewing universe. Here are a few things that have caught my roving eye lately, if you’re feeling adventurous:

headline: Cable News Networks Have Banner Year in 2016
text: For cable television stalwarts like TBS, ESPN, Discovery and Univision, 2016 was not a great year. Cord cutting remained a threat as viewership totals declined by double digits on a percentage basis, and the ratings for programs, including scripted dramas and sports, on cable and broadcast TV proved, yet again, that fewer people are watching live.

headline: Lella Vignelli, a Designer With a Spare, Elegant Style, Dies at 82
text: Lella Vignelli, a designer who, with her husband, Massimo Vignelli, introduced a spare, elegant style to a wide range of products and corporate brands, attracting an international clientele, died on Dec. 22 at her home in Manhattan. She was 82.

headline: Celtics and Grizzlies Are Good. In This N.B.A., That’s a Problem.
text: BOSTON — Isaiah Thomas, the starting point guard for the Boston Celtics, was ice skating with his young children on Monday when he learned that he had been named the N.B.A.’s Eastern Conference player of the week. His father, he said, had texted him to share the news.

headline: Hans Tietmeyer, Banker Who Led German Transition to Euro, Dies at 85

headline: 85-Year-Old Marathoner Is So Fast That Even Scientists Marvel
text: MILTON, Ontario — It was a day for talking, not running. Snow was piled along the streets. The driveway was icy. Ed Whitlock’s shoulder hurt. His face had been puffy. He did not feel well enough for the cemetery.

headline: Quotation of the Day
text: “It’s essentially the serial killer of drugs. It’s not something you can use for any kind of duration and survive.”

headline: Religious Police Officers in New York Will Be Able to Wear Beards and Turbans
text: In a nod to the growing number of South Asian Sikhs in New York City, the Police Department said on Wednesday that it would allow officers who belong to the religion to wear beards and turbans while in uniform — as long as the turbans are blue.

headline: Vesna Vulovic, Flight Attendant Who Survived Jetliner Blast, Dies at 66
text: Vesna Vulovic, a flight attendant who alone, and miraculously, survived the midair explosion of a jetliner over Czechoslovakia in 1972 after plummeting thousands of feet onto a snowy hill, was reported dead on Saturday in Belgrade. She was 66.

headline: As China’s Largest Freshwater Lake Shrinks, Solution Faces Criticism
text: HONG KONG — Long celebrated as China’s largest freshwater lake, Poyang reaches more than three times the expanse of Los Angeles in the summer wet season. It is home to the rare Yangtze finless porpoise, and its mud flats are the primary winter feeding grounds for thousands of birds that fly south each autumn to escape Siberia’s chill, including the critically endangered Siberian crane.

headline: Tillerson Led Exxon’s Shift on Climate Change; Some Say ‘It Was All P.R.’
text: In January 2009, Rex W. Tillerson, the chief executive of Exxon Mobil, gave a speech in Washington that might have seemed impossible even a few years before. He announced that his company supported a carbon tax to help fight climate change.

headline: Kerry’s Blunt Words for Israel Denounced by Lawmakers in Both Parties
text: Secretary of State John Kerry’s rebuke of the Israeli government on Wednesday set off a wave of criticism from lawmakers in both parties. Republicans denounced what they said was the Obama administration’s harsh treatment of a steadfast ally and Democrats signaled that they were uneasy with Mr. Kerry’s pressure on Israel, even as they praised the effort to promote Middle East peace.

headline: A Maple Leafs Museum and Man Cave, All in One Basement
text: TORONTO — It is a dark and rainy night when about a dozen members of the Conacher family descend the steps into Mike Wilson’s basement.

headline: Is Israel Abandoning a Two-State Solution?
text: Over the past week, differences between Israel and the United States have boiled over into a scalding diplomatic confrontation between these closest of allies. The dispute reflects not any change in American policy, but a dangerous evolution in Israeli policy, under the government of Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, away from an acceptance of a negotiated two-state resolution to Israel’s conflict with the Palestinians. The dispute also arises from Mr. Netanyahu’s lamentable practice of making his government a more nakedly partisan player in American politics than any foreign government in memory, save Russia.

headline: The Honesty of Carrie Fisher
text: Oh, Carrie Fisher, gone way too soon. And now your mother, Debbie Reynolds. The startling loss this week of one of Hollywood’s great mother-daughter pairs was another blow in an unnerving year. You could call it a Hollywood ending, if by that you mean one that is larger and weirder than real life, and that tugs mightily at strong emotions.

headline: Debbie Reynolds, Wholesome Ingénue in 1950s Films, Dies at 84
text: Debbie Reynolds, the wholesome ingénue in 1950s films like “Singin’ in the Rain” and “Tammy and the Bachelor,” died on Wednesday, a day after the death of her daughter, the actress Carrie Fisher. She was 84.

headline: Edwin Goldwasser, Physicist Who Co-Founded Fermilab, Dies at 97
text: Edwin Goldwasser, a physicist who co-founded the Fermi National Accelerator Laboratory in Batavia, Ill., and helped build one of the world’s most powerful particle accelerators, died on Dec. 14 at his home in Urbana, Ill. He was 97.

headline: Bibi Netanyahu Makes Trump His Chump
text: For those of you confused over the latest fight between President Obama and Prime Minister Bibi Netanyahu of Israel, let me make it simple: Barack Obama and John Kerry admire and want to preserve Israel as a Jewish and democratic state in the Land of Israel. I have covered this issue my entire adult life and have never met two U.S. leaders more committed to Israel as a Jewish democracy.

headline: The Devotion of an Old-Fashioned Doctor in Romania
text: As a little girl, Ioana Moldovan eagerly awaited her vacations at her grandfather’s house in southwestern Transylvania. He lived in a steel mill town, where he raised rows of tomatoes, cucumbers, strawberries, cranberries and cherries, which Ms. Moldovan would eat directly from the trees. While her grandfather, Ion Ciugudean, did not talk much about his work as a radiologist, he did seem to know everyone in the village. Whenever he would go to the market, shopkeepers and customers would say hello and treat him with the same respect he treated his patients.

headline: China Warmly Welcomes a Giant Rooster With Trumpian Characteristics
text: HONG KONG — President-elect Donald J. Trump’s golden quiff, bushy eyebrows and preening gestures were immortalized this week in China — though perhaps not in a way that he would like.

headline: Letter of Recommendation: Not Breathing
text: A few years ago I went snorkeling with my sister, and she startled a sea lion. Rather, I was snorkeling, and my sister was free diving — that is, diving much deeper, and holding her breath much longer. She had swum down to the ocean floor to inspect something, and as she glided up from the depths, the sea lion approached from out in the hazy blue. It was moving casually, but casual for a waterborne marine creature is still pretty fast. When it finally noticed my sister cruising through a space where humans normally are not, it pulled up, coming to a sudden halt, vertical in the water. The sea lion looked amazed and delighted — at least, that’s how it looked to me, looking at my sister — and at that moment, the thing I wanted most in the world was to learn how to hold my breath and dive deep long enough so that I might also startle and amaze someone, or something, like a sea lion.

headline: Judge John Hodgman on Forced Friendships
text: Taylor writes: I believe that my roommate Zoe and I could be friends. But even though she lives in my house, I don’t know how to approach her. It’s a big house, and we live at opposite ends. Still, she seems cool and I’d like to get to know her better. I think she would be more convinced if you told her to give it a try. Please order Zoe to be my friend.

headline: The Evangelical Scion Who Stopped Believing
text: One morning in the summer of 2011 Bart Campolo left his house in Cincinnati for a long bicycle ride. Goateed and bald, but still trim and fit at 48, Campolo was the envy of his generation of evangelical pastors. That morning, Campolo was, as usual, a little self-conscious about his attire. “I feel ridiculous in my spandex,” he says. Years of pickup basketball had wrecked his ankles, leaving regular bicycle treks as his only form of exercise. But he was excited to do 30 or 40 miles through the rolling southern Ohio hills.

headline: On Your Way to Your New Year’s Self
text: Maybe you have some ideas about the new year, as I do, and you’ve dedicated substantial minutes considering what version of yourself you’d like to cultivate in the coming months. You think you’d like to eat better. To have more adventures. Take more risks. Maybe you are moving to Canada and want to learn to speak French. In any case, you resolve that you are going to wake up on New Year’s Day, invigorated by the fresh start laid out in front of you like new snow on a school morning, and make some serious tracks.

headline: The Biggest Digital Map of the Cosmos Ever Made

Over the next four years, Pan-Starrs, short for Panoramic Survey Telescope and Rapid Response System, photographed the entire sky, as seen from Hawaii, 12 times in five colors of visible and infrared light.

headline: We Need to Talk About Kanye
text: This year has been especially heavy with untimely popular culture deaths. In the past week, George Michael and Carrie Fisher joined that tally. Neither was entirely comfortable with fame, even though Ms. Fisher, as the daughter of Debbie Reynolds and Eddie Fisher, was born with fame virtually in her bloodstream. Her ambivalence always seemed healthy even when she herself was not. Their deaths are an occasion to think about the toll fame takes on a person, not only on the dead but also on the living. What if that person is Kanye West?
